BREAK.PARA: What needs to be recognised at the outset is that there is a six-month period for people to pay those bonds under the Aged Care Act, and they cannot be required to pay earlier. It is as simple as that; there are six months before they have to pay. Also, providers who act outside that act are acting illegally, and the act can be used to full effect to address that particular matter.

The other matter that the member raised was other methods by which people might meet their obligations under the proposed bond system. One is described as the periodic payment arrangements. The bond can be paid in a lump sum, as I have mentioned, or they can make an equivalent weekly or fortnightly periodic payment made up of the retention amount of $2,600 plus the component for interest. They can pay part as a lump sum or part as a periodic payment, whichever option suits them. This is a very flexible system. They can also, as the member indicated in his question—I can confirm that it is a fact—agree that the retention amount and the interest be taken from their estate, if that is what they want to do.

The important thing that has not been raised in this debate is that this is a system that is needs based, not means based. In other words, if someone needs to go into a hostel or a nursing home, they are assessed by an ACATS team, an aged care assessment team. If those assessments show that they should go into care, they go along to that home and seek an agreement with regard to the bond in the terms that I have just outlined. So there is no up-front fee, as has been stated by many in the Labor Party.

There is another point that I want to make. All the industry agreed with the following matter. There are provisions in the act under section 57(xii)—the shadow spokesman will be aware of this—that provides that the maximum accommodation bond that can be charged is lesser than the amount specified in the accommodation bond agreement, the amount such that it leaves the person with assets of $22,500 or an amount specified or worked out in accordance with the user rights principles. —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. Can the Minister for Defence inform the House what is being done to combat illegal fishing in the Heard and McDonald Islands exclusive economic zone?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McLachlan, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Swan for his question. I will give a straight answer to this question. The government has been concerned for some time about reports of illegal fishing in our exclusive economic zone around the Heard and McDonald Islands in the Southern Ocean. As we know, this illegal fishing breaches Australia's sovereign rights, is anti‐conservation, kills many seabirds and is not in the interests of our fishing industry. Last August cabinet directed that the Australian Defence Force mount an operation against this illegal fishing activity.

ANSWER.PARA: Last Thursday and Friday our newest frigate, HMAS Anzac, apprehended two foreign vessels operating in the vicinity of that exclusive economic zone. The boats are the Salvora, registered in Belize, and the Aliza Glacial, registered in Panama. As I speak, they are being escorted to Fremantle and to an appearance for their masters in an Australian court. The masters of both these vessels can be charged under the Fisheries Management Act. The penalties for illegal foreign fishing can include fines of up to $250,000 and forfeiture of the vessels, gear and the catch.

I have to say that the operation has been an outstanding success for the Defence Force and, once again, shows their very high level of morale and professionalism and training. They are working in very hazardous conditions down there in subantarctic waters. Just for the interest of members, it is 1½ times further south than the area where we rescued Tony Bullimore and Monsieur Dubois last year. In other words, it is about 4,000 kilometres south of Perth. Despite these difficulties, it is just business as usual—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought members might be interested in this. Despite the fact that there were some difficulties, this business—
—You are taking a long time to get around to it.

—It ought to interest you because it is south of your neck of the woods. The matter is business as usual for the Defence Force, and I would like to acknowledge the help given to us by France, which also must deal with illegal fishing in that area. The cooperation between our forces was an important factor.
—Tell us about the $1 billion lost.

—Don't you read the newspapers?

—Well, we are getting some of it back. In conducting this task, I have to say that departments worked closely together: the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, Foreign Affairs, Environment, Sport and Attorney‐General's. I want to repeat that the government is committed to protecting our sovereignty in these areas and it is our plan to make sure that illegal fishing operations find the cost of breaking the Australian law far too high.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Aboriginal and Islander Sexual Health Strategy

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Can the minister advise the House of progress on the implementation of the government's initiatives under the indigenous sexual health strategy? What have been the developments since the strategy was announced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and his interest. In March this year I informed the House about the national Aboriginal and Islander sexual health strategy, something that we had worked for a year with to get consensus amongst Aboriginal groups as to a way we could move forward in this very difficult area. Since then we have utilised the framework agreements that we have signed with states. That means that for the first time we have had the state governments, ATSIC, Aboriginal community controlled organisations and the Commonwealth government sitting down together trying to work out a common strategy. We have worked on the basis of what underpins the sexual health strategy—that is, quality primary health care and a population approach to sexual health, which is a very big change from what has been tried in the past, which is stand‐alone education.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to inform the House that the first agreement has been reached with the Queensland state government whereby we will be contributing $1.8 million over the next 12 months to programs in four main areas. The first is that we will be funding externally funded agencies. The second is that we will be providing clinical services in six deed of grant communities. The third is that we will be providing 12 community sexual health programs. Finally, we will be doing a well person screening program, and this is very exciting. It is essentially a joint venture between the Queensland government and non‐government agencies, in particular Apunipima Aboriginal health service based at Cairns, in the member for Leichhardt's electorate. The director of this is Barbara Flick, who is known to many people in the House who have an interest in Aboriginal health matters.

This is terribly exciting. It draws on the experience of the tri‐state project which ran in the Northern Territory‐South Australian‐WA border area. Kerry Arabena, who was the coordinator of that, has moved to Cairns and it is actually her leadership and vision that has got this up and running. What is going to happen is that we will focus on a population basis to try to get rid of some of the large residual population of untreated and asymptomatic sexually transmitted diseases that in the end make this area so difficult to address. Because there is obviously difficulty and some stigma associated with it, the screening will not just be for sexually transmitted diseases but will also involve diabetes, liver disease and heart disease.

We will be using the latest polymerase chain reaction techniques to test for gonorrhoea and chlamydia and, we hope, within 12 months for donovanosis. We will also be utilising the latest single dose therapies. I would very much like to congratulate everyone involved and those who have worked so hard to make this come about. It is an exciting prospect.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Moreton for his question and acknowledge the great interest he has in foreign affairs issues, including Australia's development assistance program. ANSWER.PARA: Now that we are halfway through the life of this parliament, we look to see the development of policies of the Australian Labor Party. And imagine my pleasure when I saw on Monday morning an article in the Australian newspaper headed `ALP won't trade on foreign aid spending'—an article reporting the member for Kingsford‐Smith's policy position on Australia's aid program. There was a good point in the member for Kingsford‐Smith's policy. That was that the Labor Party has apparently endorsed the government's priorities in terms of the development assistance program. But I also noticed with interest that the member for Kingsford‐Smith, in developing Labor's policies, has identified the fact that Labor would reach 0.4 per cent of GNP aid spending by the year 2005.

That may be all very well but, when you are a major political party and when you are the opposition, you also have to explain to the Australian people not just what your target is but how you are going to reach your target and how you are going to pay for it. The question on our lips is: `How is the Labor Party going to pay for this?' To achieve that target, I am advised, they would have to raise somewhere in the vicinity of $7 billion by 2005.

You can come to one of two conclusions. If they are going to spend an additional $7 billion, where are they going to get the money from? Are they going to cut the money from schools? Are they going to cut the money from hospital funding? Or is it going to come from nursing home capital programs? The point is that, if you put forward a policy like this, you ought to have the decency to tell the Australian people how you are going to pay for the policy. You have said absolutely nothing about that, which leads one to draw the reasonable conclusion that this policy is nothing more than a repetition of the deceit we had during the last election.

Members may recall that in February 1996 the now Deputy Leader of the Opposition went around claiming that Labor would absolutely increase aid to 0.4 per cent of GNP. This was an absolutely firm commitment—until we pointed out that it would cost you in those days $1.2 billion to do it. You had a hole in your budget and four days later—I think it was—you made another statement to the effect, `Oh well, that's our aspiration; I'm not sure whether we would ever reach it.'

For those with an even longer memory, let me tell them that in 1993 John Kerin, as the Minister for Development Assistance in those days, said that during `the life of the next parliament'—the 1993‐96 parliament—`Labor would increase aid spending up to 0.4 per cent of GNP'. That is what he said. And what happened? It went from 0.36 per cent down to 0.33 per cent.

So we have had deceit from the Labor Party in the 1993 election and the 1996 election. When it comes to the 1998 or 1999 election, let us see where you are going to get the money from. Explain that to the Australian public, because the fact is that we are past the mid‐point of this parliament now and it is incumbent on the Labor Party not just to stand up here and ask questions about existing government policies but to explain how you will pay for all the things you claim you would do. You have no idea how you will do it and you will not get away with that with the Australian electorate.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs. Is the minister aware of the difficulties consumers have in identifying truly Australian orange juice? Juice reconstituted from imported concentrate is often packaged with the words `made in Australia' included on it. What is the government doing to prevent misleading country of origin claims being made about orange juice, particularly when it is packaged using imported concentrate, particularly concentrate from Brazil?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Truss, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Mallee for his question and I am certainly conscious of the tremendous work that he does in representing the citrus growers of his region and his longstanding advocacy of truth in labelling laws.

ANSWER.PARA: This issue is certainly one that has been of concern to Australian citrus growers and, of course, to consumers. Indeed, a number of other people have accentuated these concerns by making claims that citrus juice labelled `made in Australia' is, in fact, of Brazilian origin. The member for Oxley, who I notice is absent today—

TALK.START.PARA: —Again!

—Yes, absent again. She was asking questions about this subject and in fact made allegations in the House that Brazilian citrus juice was being labelled `made in Australia'. The fact is that fruit growers have a right to be concerned when these sorts of claims are being made. Australian citrus juice has an enviable reputation for its quality, and Australian growers naturally want to ensure that the integrity of claims for Australian origin are protected.

ANSWER.PARA: Many Australian consumers are prepared to pay a premium to buy an Australian product, so claims that juice is Australian when in fact it is Brazilian or from some other country can damage the public confidence in the labelling system. Origin labelling claims such as `made in Australia' and `product of Australia' are regulated at the Commonwealth level under the Trade Practices Act. The relevant provisions of that act make it abundantly clear that fruit juice that is merely reconstituted or packaged in Australia from Brazilian orange juice cannot carry such descriptors as `made in Australia' or `product of Australia'. Such claims would be a clear breach of the act. A product manufactured in Australia from imported ingredients would have to have some kind of qualified claim, such as `made in Australia with imported concentrate'.

We have a very active regulator, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, that has given a high priority to policing country of origin labelling claims. There have been a number of actions in relation to false labelling claims but not very many, I might add, in relation to country of origin. There was one recent case in relation to Florida foods in Sydney, but in that case the claims that were false on the label were multiple. There were claims that it was unsweetened when in fact it was sweetened, that it was fresh when it was not fresh and that it was Australian when there is strong evidence that some of the concentrate was imported. So there have been actions taken whenever evidence has been brought to the attention of the ACCC or the government that a false claim has been made.

I should also point out that the ACCC, along with the Australian Fruit Juice Association, has produced a code of practice aimed at preventing misleading practices in the industry. An industry complaints body determines the most appropriate sanction when a breach occurs. Of course, the ACCC can also act if there is a need for enforcement action.

The member for Mallee is as well aware as many others that this government inherited a product labelling system that was seriously flawed. We are acting to restore the integrity of the system. If anyone has a particular concern that a product is falsely labelled as Australian when it is imported then we want to know about it. If the member for Oxley can substantiate her claims that Brazilian orange juice is being labelled as Australian, we want to know about it and we will take action. If she cannot substantiate her claims then she should not seek to damage the confidence of the Australian people in the Australian fruit juice industry. This government is determined to ensure that consumers are told the truth about the origin of fruit juice and the Australian citrus industry can be assured of our determination to act in the area.

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Government for forcing elderly Australians to sell the family home for what is a form of health care traditionally provided by the whole community for those who need to enter a nursing home.

What we have seen today from the new Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) is a small soupcon of a problem that has been confronted by elderly people all over Australia today as they confront this new uncertainty in their lives. The way in which the government like to clothe themselves here in this chamber is that they have found a brilliant way in which to fund nursing homes in this country—a fair way, an equitable way, a non-confiscatory way. They criticised the previous government for rebasing aged care, and massively expanding expenditure on aged care. This was because we pursued a policy to, as far as possible, keep people in their houses as long as possible and provide a whole variety of alternative services—and, in the process, in the course of a decade, in that period of time doubling expenditure on aged care. They have sought to demonise that particular policy, say it was inadequate, and then assume that we will not actually read their budget papers to see precisely what they are up to.

Yesterday we had this minister up here, with his little chart, saying, `This is where there's been a decline thus far in expenditure under the previous government,' as far as funding for nursing home capital provision was concerned. Yesterday he was up there doing that particular exercise and he was caught out, because he stood in ignorance of the fact that some $300 million specifically in nursing home capital funds was boastfully extracted from the budget—indeed, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) thought it good enough to mention in his speech—and the burden of care placed directly on the people who were entering nursing homes.

The minister stood in ignorance of that yesterday. Then today he had the hide to get up in this place and pretend in his first answer—until finally, over three questions, we beat him down to what the actual reality is. We finally beat him down to that position; he finally admitted, `Yes, not one red cent of this increased fee that is coming in on 1 November is, in fact, going to go to additional provision for nursing homes'—not one red cent. That is a direct take out of patients in nursing homes put in the bank‐kick of the government. That is precisely what the intention of that policy was.

BREAK.PARA: What this government has tried to do, as it has gone down this road, is to clothe itself with some sort of protection via what was done in hostels by the previous government. Let me get on to the difference between hostels and nursing homes because, while 100 per cent of Australians outside this chamber understand the difference between hostels and nursing homes, only one-third of the Australians inside this chamber understand that difference.

But let us tell you what we did. It is true that in the area of hostels we did bring into place a means tested provision for those who were entering those hostels; at the same time, we massively increased public funding for hostels. So for people who needed to access it, because they were in a situation where they could not afford it, the government was putting money towards their position. On top of that, there was an additional provision associated with hostels that was a means tested co-payment.

But what did this government do? It went in the opposite direction. Not only did it put in place a proposition, as far as nursing homes were concerned, which would strip those entering them of their assets down to $22,500; it also extracted all the public funding associated with capital provision for nursing homes. That is what this government did. To clothe yourselves even with one iota of protection from what the previous government did, in pursuing a massively generous policy to aged care assistance, with this little piece of chicanery is simply adding a personal disgrace to your public disgrace as far as this issue of nursing homes is concerned.

Let me go through the difference between hostels and nursing homes for that exclusive little group immediately opposite us which needs an explanation—and I apologise to the gallery for boring them to tears while I go through this process. To compare a hostel with a nursing home is like saying that a hotel is the same as a hospital because there are beds in it. That is the relevance of the comparison. The simple fact of the matter is that nursing homes now, and nursing homes increasingly, are occupied exclusively by the most frail and ill amongst the aged. If they are in that situation, they are not in hostels. Only if they happen to be in that situation of extremity now do they get into nursing homes.
It was our intention when we were in office to attempt to provide a situation where most people lived their lives out in the circumstances in which they most found desirable.

TALK.START.PARA: —In their own homes.

—Which is, of course, in their own homes. We therefore massively increased home and community care—massively. You, of course, in this budget, I might say, have cut that, against your particular election promises. But we massively increased home and community care. We acknowledged that people, aside from what they might do in their own homes, were also moving into different styles of living, and that hostels were becoming less relevant for large numbers of them. Nevertheless, we increased provision for accommodation in hostels, we increased support for hostels, while we were in office so that people would be able to take those choices.

BREAK.PARA: We acknowledged that, as we did all of these things, increasingly nursing homes were going to find themselves bearing the burden of the frailest and the most vulnerable in our society. That is why we treat them differently. That is why in opposition we treat them differently, and that is why when we return to government we will treat them differently.

The Treasurer decided to mock what we would do. What has this particular piece of chicanery against the elderly in our community produced? It has contributed to a surplus that is now openly touted around the Liberal Party as a slush fund for their next election campaign. In order to introduce their value added tax, the GST, they are openly meandering around the place saying, `We are going to get offsetting cuts in the income tax area we are out of; our surplus.'

What else do they find about that surplus? After having demonised us for about 10 months and having shattered confidence in this community in their ignorant process, they are finding that their surplus on receipts of company tax in particular is higher than they thought it would be. What we will not let you do is put a GST in place on the backs of the elderly in this country, which in practical terms is precisely what you are doing. We intend to set aside a proportion of this surplus to provide exactly what is required to restore those massive cuts that are being put in place in the publicly funded provision of nursing home places.

So do not worry about where the resources are coming from. I will tell you where the resources are coming from, my friend. They are coming from precisely the same place you are going to fund your retreat on this particular proposition. But it is a retreat, I am afraid, that none of the elderly will believe. They know that, were you to be re-elected, you would, like so many monkeys in a zoo, bounce out of the cage again to perform to past practice. You would be right into it again with your little efforts to knock over the people who are going to enter those nursing homes.

It is a hypocritical position for people who two years ago were going to the elderly in this community and thanking that generation for saving Australia: `This is our thanks, team! You had an anticipation through your working life while you were paying your taxes and educating your children'. I might say that we happen to be the children; those of us who are sitting around in this place, including me. We are not talking about the tidal wave of elderly that the minister talked about the other day.

The tidal wave of elderly that you referred to, Minister, is my mum and dad and your mum and dad. That is basically it. That is what we are talking about in this tidal wave. Let us give them a name, this tidal wave of elderly that you are referring to. There is no tidal wave of elderly immediately impacting upon the situation in which this government finds itself. This is a program conceived in cynicism as far as this government is concerned, hopefully covered by a blackguarding of your predecessors when you immediately came into office. We do not happen to be about letting you get away with that.

The fact is that that generation had an anticipation. It may well be the case—it probably was the case until you wrecked the superannuation arrangements that we put in place—that people now in their 20s, 30s and 40s have an anticipation of what they must do with some of their surplus income to prepare for their old age. (4) attempting to prey on the vulnerable for political advantage."

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is seconding it?

—You should know the standing orders. When you move a motion like this you do not need an immediate seconder. Furthermore, I think the statements made by the shadow minister on the radio programs this morning bear repeating again. What I just heard the Leader of the Opposition say is, `We are going to walk away from addressing this problem. We are not going to tell people clearly what we are going to do at the next election.' But the shadow minister gave it away this morning. She said, `Labor is saying that it should be raised through the tax system.' So we are going to find at the next election that they will reject any sensible approach to redressing the taxation issues in this country. We are not going to have any meaningful taxation redress in this country. We saw what they did in 1993. A shameful, despicable scare campaign was used in 1993.
—But you lost your seat.

—I did lose my seat in 1993. Let me say this to you: I am prepared to stand up for the fundamentals of this policy and take the scorn of you and others in the community because I know it is right. You talked about my mother. Fair enough, you can be personal about it if you wish, but I want my mother and any of my relatives' parents or any of my friends' parents to be able to go into nursing homes that meet the standards that we as a sensible country would want to see.

SPEECH.PARA: I quoted figures yesterday that show there is a crisis in nursing home standards in this country, and it is something we need to address: 40 per cent live in wards with four beds or more, 13 per cent do not meet fire standards, 11 per cent do not meet health standards and many of them do not meet Australian design standards. Professor Gregory, the person who advised you in 1994, said that we have a crisis where we must redress this capital imbalance and we must take account of the age demographic movements that are all about us.

It should be a point of honour in a country like ours, where we have increasing numbers of people moving into that age demographic, that we take pride in looking for a policy solution to provide them with quality care—care that will provide them with some security, care that will provide them with some dignity, something we can be proud of. A country like ours, as it grows and venerates the aged, should make sure that the facilities into which they are able to go meet all the standards that we would want.

It is our responsibility in a national parliament—it does not matter what our politics are—to seek solutions. That is why the consultation process was taken on by my colleague the former minister, Judi Moylan. She did a good job. She consulted widely. She put together a policy that so many have endorsed. Let me give you some further quotes. Keith Woollard of the AMA said:

BREAK.PARA: The aged care reforms . . . is one way which Australia can come to terms with the massive increase in demand for quality accommodation and care of our ageing population. Now we have a government that is willing to make a tough decision that will ultimately benefit all aged care residents by providing proprietors of these facilities no excuse not to improve standards.
Why shouldn't we be improving standards? Denis Jones of the Australian Nursing Federation said:
Mrs Moylan has made a genuine effort to consult all groups involved in the massive overhaul of nursing homes.
Gary Johns I quoted earlier. You ridiculed him, but how quickly you walk away from one of the thinkers on your own side. He said:

The policy is correct. We'd already done it in hostels. I think it would only be a matter of time, if we'd remained in government, that we would have imposed it for nursing homes as well. It's logical. It's fair. It's reasonable.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) quoted yesterday the former Treasurer, the member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis). Obviously he was thinking along these positive lines as well. But what we had today from the Leader of the Opposition was, in a sense, shameful. He knows that we have to face this issue, and face it sensibly, and I have said that we will monitor the implementation process. TALK.START.PARA: —The women on your back bench don't support you.

—No amount of bluster and yelling and screaming from the opposition or attempts to misrepresent the facts are going to cloud the community's view that this government is doing what is right for the nation. Please be assured that whilst the fundamentals of the policy have been settled, I am quite happy to discuss aspects to ensure there is a greater understanding of the policy and that its implementation phase is fair to all concerned.

We are delighted to work with the government on this. We will continue to work on these with the government in a joint committee of care, said Bishop Carnley.

That is why we moved the amendment.

You are the ones who deserve to be censured because all you have done is try to yell and bluster and run around. It is not just Warwick Smith, the member for Bass, saying it; the Democrats and responsible commentators are saying that you are trying to run a scare campaign not dissimilar to what you did with tax arrangements. You are trying to position yourself by looking backwards to where Australia has come from. You are not looking forward to the problems that we face as a nation. You are not doing any thinking about how best we bring together the public policy elements to serve the needs of the aged in this community. All you are doing is ignoring it and going for the short, sharp, cheap political shot.

You gave this example—it amazes me that you should give this example—about a fee in a nursing home in Sydney. The fundamental point is that, whatever the bond is, you only take $13,000 over five years maximum and the balance is always returned. It is the same for anyone who enters into it. If you cannot get in, there are concessional beds in every home in Australia. (Time expired)

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at some of the detail. Who sent thousands of letters to nursing home residents telling them that they would have to pay more? It was the Howard government. As this article says, who sent pages of Public Service gobbledegook to people trying to arrange nursing home care, to families trying to arrange nursing home care? Of course it was this government. Many, many older Australians have written to us and have written to you as well and they have been given the complete cold shoulder treatment by this government. One lady writes:
It is a cruel irony that the very Australians who contributed so much to this nation and our quality of life are being asked to carry an unfair financial and—
most importantly—
emotional burden as their health declines.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're disgraceful.
—The member for Moreton!
—Another elderly person, a constituent from Western Australia says:

SPEECH.PARA: I am nearly seventy years of age and through circumstances not of my doing am on a full pension. This house is mine and apart from that I struggle to keep one thousand dollars in the Bank.
Under this Liberal Government the standard of living for pensioners has gone down
I still have my wits but all this has me thinking suicide . . .

The word `negotiate' is the Liberal Party word that confronts nursing home residents when they are in the hospital and have to face going into a nursing home and negotiating an entry fee of, we now discover, anything up to $250,000. Is the government going to rule out $250,000? No, they are not ruling anything out. They are not ruling $250,000 out. He had two chances today to rule out $250,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —He squibbed it.
—He squibbed it and he will continue to squib it because he does not care what the emotional burden is that this government puts on elderly Australians. Another lady, from Mosman, writes:

SPEECH.PARA: I have always voted Liberal but believe me from now on I will never ever give the Liberals my support. Any party that can target the frail aged—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's what you're doing.
—I warn the member for Moreton.
—She goes on:

BREAK.PARA: . . . to finance private entrepreneurs in this manner does not deserve the support of the elderly.
She goes on to say:
I am sure that when middle Australians wake up to the lies we have been fed in recent weeks, they will desert the Liberal Party in droves.
She too knows who is telling them misinformation. Another person, from Queensland, said:
Surveys indicate that the length of time spent in a nursing home is relatively short.

As this writer says, it is `the last port of call'. One thing that this government does not understand is that it is the last port of call. That is what is so distressing to very vulnerable people when they are facing having to go into their last port of call, which is never ever a choice that they make, never ever a choice that any elderly Australian makes to go into the last port of call, to go into the nursing home. It is not a choice to go into a nursing home and people should not be told that they have to pay these ridiculous accommodation bonds of anything up to $250,000. This author goes on to say:
It is portraying the Howard Government among the Aged Community as being quite callous and brutal and portraying them—
elderly Australians—
as greedy and selfish.

We know who it is that this Howard government is supporting. We know who it is that it goes along with in calling older Australians greedy and selfish. It is, of course, none other than Doug Moran, who thinks that these elderly Australians who have gone through the Depression and the Second World War are bludgers. That is the view of this government. That is the view of Doug Moran, that you should pay your way because otherwise you are just a bludger. A writer from New South Wales says:
Elderly people are scared of what might lay ahead for them, & their partners.
This writer says:
I beg you to do all you can to high light the plight . . .

So much for trying to stop us speaking. That is not what elderly people want; they want the Labor Party to stand up for them. They know that you won't. You correctly point out that nursing homes currently really are an extension of the hospital system.

I firmly believe that nursing homes should return to the principle of need, not profit.

I heard the minister say earlier that he believes that his system is based on needs, not means. He is as naive as the previous minister because he knows and we know that money talks. The Howard government seems to me, a 78‐year‐old pensioner, mean‐spirited, retrogressive, and on so many issues, just plain wrong‐headed.
This is from a church minister here in Canberra:

The present coalition government must go down in history as one of the most immoral to have ever governed our country. Its reduction of massive funding in the aged care area cannot be justified in any shape or form and to then abuse the aged care providers for inadequate facilities is hypocrisy on a grand scale.

Hypocrisy on a grand scale, Minister. That is how it is seen by one of the church leaders here in Canberra. They know, and you know, that this government took $500 million out of the aged care budget in 1996. So much for all your graphs. If you cared two hoots about the aged in this country, you would not have taken $500 million out of the aged care budget. Another elderly person, in a letter to you actually, Minister, says:

Why has the government so drastically cut residential aged‐care funding with the result that it will now no longer provide a basic service to its elderly citizens, a service which is regarded as an obligatory minimum in other developed and civilised nations, which, as with Australia, have religiously collected taxes over the years from the vast majority of these citizens?

It is the case, and it needs to be said to this government, that these people have paid their taxes, they have paid their dues. It is not, as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) thinks, that these people owe a debt to the Australian government. They do not owe any debt; they should not have to pay to get what is an essential service to care for them, as another writer said, in the last port of call, in a nursing home. This person continues in his letter to you:

Why is the legislation so bizarre and in my opinion both punitive and discriminatory against elderly Australians? Why has your government seen fit to make the lot of elderly and, in many cases, frail Australians so insecure . . .

Don't worry, Minister, there is no doubt out there amongst the elderly about who they think has made them insecure. It is this government that has made them insecure. It is your policies that has made them insecure, because of course it is the case that most elderly Australians have one asset and one asset alone to pay this accommodation bond. And they do have to pay it. They do have to agree to pay a sum, and these sums we now know are anything up to $250,000.

I have no doubt that homes in Launceston do not come for $250,000; they come for a lot less than $250,000. So people in Launceston who pay their up‐front fees, who pay their accommodation bonds, are going to be paying, what, $100,000 less $22,000, so maybe they will be paying $70,000. But we have no idea, do we, Minister, what the up‐front limit will be because you refuse to set a limit? You refuse to give anybody any comfort about what the limit will be. You refuse to set a limit because of course your mates in the nursing home industry do not want you to set a limit. They want to get the money; they want $250,000.

It does appear to be the case that those who are scaring elderly Australians are none other than yourselves. It is the Howard government that is scaring elderly Australians by making them sell their homes to get a nursing home bed, by making the vast majority of them have to confront something which none of them want to confront: the notion of losing their home because you took $500 million out of the budget. It is the result of this government's policies that people have to sell their homes. That is where the blame for the scare lies and that is clearly understood by elderly Australians. You will be condemned by elderly Australians for it at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would firstly like to say that I care for older people. I spent most of my working life looking after older people. I worked in an area that contained many older Australians. Honest members of any government will say that they do not always agree with everything that that government does. But I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I strongly support what the government is doing in this area of aged care, and it relates in every possible way to the care and concern that we as responsible people leading Australia should have for our older Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The Keating government, in my view, had two principal failures. Whilst the government did some very good things in its first two terms under Mr Hawke in micro‐economic reform, and in particular for hostel accommodation bonds or entry contributions in 1988, the two principal failures of the Keating government were, firstly, that it allowed us to finance social infrastructure on debt and asset sales instead of income and, secondly, that it allowed us in many ways to become a selfish country, a country in which we value our rights more highly than our responsibilities. The value of things was far more important than values under the Keating government and there was a preoccupation, by the time we took government last year, with the here and now rather than respect for the past and any kind of sensible planning for the future.

BREAK.PARA: Australians who have had the misfortune, in one sense, to listen to or see this debate today must be despairing—despairing of the confrontation, of the posturing, of the ideological invective and of the hypocrisy and manipulation, particularly from some of the speakers on the other side, in relation to this issue.

This policy in aged care addresses a number of critical issues. It recognises, firstly, Australia's rapidly increasing aged dependency ratios. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) has many positive characteristics, I am sure, but I notice that one of the negative criticisms that are made of the Leader of the Opposition is that he is light on the intellectual application to policy. He said in the course of his address, `There is no tidal wave of elderly people immediately impacting upon this government.' What he is saying is that he, as the leader of the alternative government in Australia, is incapable of looking at where Australia is going to be 10, 20 or 30 years from now.

In 1992 there were 5.3 Australians between the ages of 15 and 64 for every person under the age of 15 or over the age of 64. It is called an age dependency ratio. In 40 years time that ratio will be 2.6:1. If you read the National Commission of Audit report under the chairmanship of Professor Bob Officer last year, you will find that over the next 40 years we are going to have to spend 10 per cent more of our gross domestic product on the health and welfare costs of ageing. By the year 2001 about 13½ per cent of us will be over the age of 65. Halfway through next century, almost a third of Australia will be over the age of 65 and, in the absence of a cure, approximately eight per cent of us over the age of 75 will suffer from dementia.

This policy is not about harvesting votes from people who are justifiably cynical of the politicians who represent them in the political process. It is not about trying to capture the votes of people whose fears can be easily manipulated. It is about creating the kind of Australia in which when any of us eventually need care—and about five per cent of Australians eventually need residential aged care—a place will be available for us and it will be a place of quality and one in which we would be happy to have our own mother or our own father live. Whilst many nursing homes, including the Rose Bay nursing home that the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) referred to, are places that I would be proud to live in or have my mother in, there are many nursing homes that are not. If you look at what the previous government did in doing very good things in introducing this system into the hostel sector, you will see that it failed dismally to put sufficient funding into capital stock and care needs in the nursing home sector.

What the policy also does is change cultural expectations. I said that one of the two principal failures of the Keating government was allowing us to become a selfish country. This policy changes an expectation so that young people, perhaps like me—although I am probably not that young any more—have to start thinking about who is going to finance our education, who is going to look after us when we are old, recognising, as I said earlier, that Australia cannot possibly afford, no matter how noble the proposition, to finance the aged residential care entirely for all Australians.

So at some point a government that has vision and is concerned for people has to do what we are doing. Some people on this side of the House, at great risk to themselves and their own political careers, are supporting this policy because they know it is the subject of political manipulation and misrepresentation on the other side. But they are doing it because they are here to change the country; they are not here to simply be here and get themselves re-elected all the time.

The third thing this policy does is provide much needed money for capital through the accommodation bonds, through daily fees which will supplement the costs of providing care and through a new resident classification instrument. For example, at the moment 40 per cent of people living in hostels in Australia have levels of dependency and levels of need that should actually require them to be in a nursing home. You remember all the handwringing from the opposition when in government about dementia and how we had to put more money into dementia care. Do you know that these reforms will deliver a 30 per cent increase in funding for dementia care for people that are currently living in hostels and being underresourced under the policies of the previous government.

It also amalgamates the nursing home and the hostel sector. We are saying to an aged couple that, when they go into a residential care facility, if one of them has the misfortune to have a stroke or suffer another disability, they do not have to be separated any more, they do not have to have one go to a nursing home after 50 or 60 years of marriage and find that they are separated and have the grief that goes with that.

Also, for the first time ever in Australia's nursing home industry we are going to have prospective residents, their families, their lawyer, their accountant, whoever they want to be with them, standing at the door of a nursing home and saying, `If you think I'm going to pay $2,600 a year plus an interest stream to live in this dump, you've got another thing coming.' In other words, there will be strong financial incentives for not only the resident but also some relatives who have a very keen interest in their financial affairs to question the quality of what the person they love is about to receive.

The Australian Labor Party went to the last election with a policy on aged care that was 210 words. If you read the policy, if you read between the lines, you will see that they would have done in government precisely what we are doing now—the same thing that Ms Cheryl Kernot supported and, I am sure, being the person of integrity that she is, will continue to support. The bonds that we are perhaps asking people to pay when they go into a nursing home will deliver $1.5 billion over the next 10 years to the capital stock and accommodation within which our older Australians live. In the last year the opposition were in government, they committed not $1.5 billion to nursing home capital stock but $12 million. As a part of our package we are actually putting $40 million just into capital stock for nursing homes in regional and rural areas, not to mention the additional money that is going in to support people who are concessional residents who clearly cannot afford to meet an accommodation bond.

In 1994 Professor Bob Gregory was one of three major reviewers of the state of Australia's residential aged care and, in presenting one of the most detailed documentations of the situation, he found amongst other things that we needed to spend as Australians $1 billion in 1994 to bring our nursing homes up to meet fire, design, health and outcome standards. The Australian Office of Valuation Studies, for example, found that 13 per cent of nursing homes do not meet fire standards. Does the member for Jagajaga or the Leader of the Opposition want to continue to preside over a policy that in 1994 had delivered that? Seventy‐five per cent of nursing homes in 1994—after 11 years of Labor government and policy to which they want to revert—either had to be completely fixed or completely demolished and rebuilt.

The bond that we are asking people to pay can be paid as a single payment. If it is negotiated to $30,000, $40,000, $50,000 or $100,000, a person can say, `I will pay that into a prudentially controlled and regulated fund.' When they leave the nursing home—the average length of stay is 22 months but, sadly, 50.7 per cent of people do not live longer than a year and 37.7 per cent will not live longer than six months—they will receive all of their money back minus $2,600 a year, six months in arrears plus the interest that would be normally earned on that bond.

Do you know what the money has to be spent on? Cheryl Kernot, to her great credit, worked with Mrs Judi Moylan as the minister and she required—and this was totally supported by the government—that the money be spent on one thing only: the capital accommodation—the dwelling—in which that person lives. Or it can be spent on retiring debt that has been used to improve the accommodation or on the care of that person. It cannot be siphoned off as profit. It cannot be taken anywhere except to be spent on that particular person.

Alternatively, you might say, `Right, I have agreed my bond is going to be $50,000. I won't pay $50,000; instead I will pay $2,600 a year plus the interest that would normally accrue to $50,000. I will pay it every month, and my family loves me so much that they are going to help me pay it.' With the third option you may say, `I don't want to interfere with my finances in any way. I will take that $2,600 a year plus the interest normally earned as a debt against my estate. So I know that whenever I pass on, after whatever period I am in the home, you can take the money that is being spent on me—my accommodation and care—from my estate.' Having spent a number of years looking after frail, elderly people, I would question the motive of any relative that does not like that.

Yes, the generation that is immediately affected by this, to which the member for Jagajaga has referred, is a generation who went to war. They sent their husbands to war. They sent their sons and daughters to war. They lived through depressions. Their sacrifices made this country what it is. They did not buy something until they had saved up for it. They valued their responsibilities far more highly than their rights. They have led this country for 100 years, and in one sense they are going to lead us for the next 100 because this change, unpopular as it is when it is the subject of manipulation and distortion, is going to lead Australia into the next millennium and provide us with a finance system for residential aged care which is sustainable.

Sometimes it is important in this place to remember why we are here. We are not here to serve the political interests of the Liberal Party, the National Party, the Labor Party or those who cannot make up their mind. We are here to serve the interests of Australia, and sometimes you actually have to put aside your personal invective, you have to put aside some of your emotion and you have to do what is right. This policy is right. It might have one or two rough edges around it, but from the outset Minister Moylan and Minister Smith have been working with the industry and consumers to make sure that it works, and on 24 June 1997 the Australian Catholic Health Care Association expressed its gratitude to all members of the federal parliament for its reception of the association's concerns and suggestions. I call on the opposition to support this in the interests of Australia, not in the interests of political self‐interest. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

In doing so, I add that I do it with considerable reluctance and only because of the government's strong commitment to law enforcement. One of the bill's principal purposes is to authorise nominated members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to issue interception and listening device warrants for law enforcement purposes. The Senate's amendments include a sunset clause to come into effect at the end of 1999 on the provisions enabling AAT members to issue warrants. The other amendments are to require each annual report to include infor mation about the availability of judges to issue warrants and to require the 1999‐2000 annual report to contain a review of amendments made by the bill.

The opposition's amendments are illogical and unnecessary. In fact, reading the sunset clause and the reporting requirement together, the amendments are plainly stupid. They impose a time limit on the warrant issuing arrangements which will bring those arrangements to an end a full year ahead of the date by which the amendments require a report on the working of those arrangements. In addition, the whole telecommunications interception and listening device regime already contains extensive reporting requirements and strict controls. Moreover, the opposition chooses to ignore the practical reality that the federal judges who presently issue the warrants have decided collegiately to stop performing the function. The judges have decided that it is not a proper function for judges to perform, notwithstanding that the legislation conferring the function on them is valid. The function has been held to be an administrative not a judicial function. Accordingly, judges cannot be forced to perform the function.

Labor was aware of this problem in government. It did not, and has not yet, come up with a workable alternative. This government has provided an appropriate solution, yet the opposition says that this solution should cease to operate in two years time. One might ask whom the opposition proposes will then issue the warrants. Despite the empty posturing by the opposition parties about their commitment to fighting serious crime, what they have done in effect is to provide a temporary remedy which requires the parliament to revisit the same problem in under two years time.

Despite their obvious faults, the government will accept the amendments. The government is taking this course because, unlike Labor, it is serious about fighting crime and does not want to delay the other important amendments in the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is pleasing that the government is accepting these amendments. This was a compromise that was reached with other parties in the Senate and it is an appropriate compromise. The fact of the matter is that, when Grollo's case was determined by the highest court in this land, it was an overwhelming majority decision that this was a proper function for judicial officers. The legislation was held to be valid. There are ways around this. This Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) could appoint more judges. This Attorney‐General, in conjunction with the chief judge of the Federal Court, could organise for duty judges in each of the states so that there is not a situation where every judge of the Federal Court would be required to look at the warrant situation. There are ways around this.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very intrusive and invasive procedure. There are practices in other jurisdictions around the world and a proper reading of Grollo's case shows that the majority decision found it was appropriate. We are not happy with the amendments either because we think the Attorney‐General should start acting like an Attorney‐General and that he should not be dictated to by the judges. This is a proper function. But the problem, unfortunately, is that the bean counters have got to this Attorney‐General.

There is a sunset clause for two years time and hopefully the existing position with Federal Court judges will be cleaned out of the system. You can also have a situation where the Chief Judge of the Federal Court, in two years time, can ensure that it is only certain judges who will perform these functions so that you do not have the whole of the Federal Court tied up in this area. I can give you this undertaking: in two years time, if there is a new government, the new government will not be looking to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to perform this function, which we think is totally inappropriate. That is why there is a two‐year sunset clause; we hope there will be a new government at the end of this government's current term. One term is enough for this government.

We do welcome the fact that the government is accepting these amendments and it should be a matter of record that this is not a situation where we are totally happy with the amendments either; this is a compromise. But, in the intervening period, what it will allow to happen is that the Chief Judge of the Federal Court can bring in a system for the future, beyond the two years, that will see not all judges of the Federal Court performing this function. And there will not be any turnaround by a new Labor government. We will give sufficient resources to the Federal Court and to the judiciary, because that is part of the concept of a decent and humane society—access to justice.

The trouble with this government is that they go against the separation of powers. The separation of powers was tested in Grollo's case where this function was held, by an overwhelming majority of the High Court, to be an appropriate function for Federal Court judges to perform. I do not think it is satisfactory for the Chief Judge of the Federal Court to say to the Attorney-General, `We do not want to do this.' Then the appropriate response to that is, `That is your duty in terms of'—

TALK.START.PARA: —The High Court said it is not your duty.
—This is where the situation is. The legislation was held to be valid by the High Court. There was an amendment to the legislation; that legislation was tested.
—Judges do it by consent.

—I say this to you, Mr Deputy Speaker: there are plenty of people who would be happy to take Federal Court appointments and consent to do this function in return for being appointed to the Federal Court. Is the Attorney telling us that he cannot find anyone to consent to this procedure? That is a nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is that a proper balance has to be found. We are not saying that every judge of the Federal Court should perform this function. But this is a very important function to be performed by judges, and that is why we support a sunset clause. I welcome the backdown by the government in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I too support the amendment providing for a sunset clause in this particular change. I was interested in coming in and listening to the comments of the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) and ascertaining the reason for the government deciding to accept these particular modifications from the Senate. I was interested because I would have thought the Attorney-General, being a staunch civil libertarian, would have been concerned, in the first instance, as to how the allocation or authorisation of Administrative Appeals Tribunal officers or members to issue telecommunication interceptions and listening device warrants would be a change—a significant change—in the balance between the interests of criminal law enforcement and civil liberties.

SPEECH.PARA: As a former police officer, as someone who has had an interest and has functioned in the criminal justice system, albeit probably in a lowlier position than that occupied in the past by the Attorney-General, I would have thought it part of the Liberal Party's philosophy to strengthen the civil liberties of a citizen against the state.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no longer a Liberal Party; it is a Conservative Party.

—This is a party, unfortunately, in the case of criminal law enforcement, that is more interested, perhaps more driven, by the interests of the bottom line, as the member for Banks (Mr Melham) has said—the sort of bean counter approach. I am sure that the Attorney-General, now that he is in cabinet, is in a much stronger position. The new minister for sport may be interested to know that I am, and have been, a very strong, very staunch supporter of the elevation of the Attorney-General to cabinet. The fact that he is now there means that there is a very significant addition to the voice of Western Australia in the cabinet, amongst other things.

SPEECH.PARA: But, in particular, I know of the Attorney's reputation as a staunch civil libertarian, as somebody who would rather stand alongside the interests of the citizen versus the state rather than the executive versus the citizen. That he now is in a better position may be the reason why the government is now persuaded to accept these particular compromises—it is perhaps because he now is in the cabinet to represent the interests of the civil liberties of the Australian citizen.

BREAK.PARA: We know that there is an awesome arsenal of resources and facilities available to the state in its weaponry to take on the citizens, particularly in the criminal law enforcement area. As the member for Banks has indicated, given the decision in the Grollo case, one would have assumed that it would have been preferable to have appointed more judges who would have been prepared to consent to taking on the role of hearing and considering applications for the issue of telecommunication intercepts and warrants. However, presumably because it is far more expensive to do that, the government has opted to have what I consider to be a highly unacceptable alternative of appointing or authorising AAT members.

As I indicated in my speech during the second reading debate, there has been an awesome explosion of tribunals and the like to hear just about every single type of complaint under the sun. I would have thought that, as a person committed to strengthening the civil liberties of individual citizens, the Attorney-General would have been loath to have seen what is, in effect, a lower status judicial officer having the authority to issue what are very awesome instruments—telecommunication interception listening device warrants.

These are awesome instruments because they have the opportunity of stepping into the life of a citizen in the guise of an investigation and of being able to be used to intrude very heavily into the privacy of a citizen, if that is considered to be applicable. I would have thought the higher the level of the judicial officer or the judge listening to an application from the relevant law enforcement agency for one of these warrants, the better. Even I, as a former police officer who knows of the delays that that sometimes may involve, considering the balance of those interests—the interests of the citizen versus the state—would have thought that a fair and reasonable balance.

However, given that we have had the Senate pass a number of amendments, I am pleased to see that they at least relate to the question of a sunset clause and to the information—of the availability of judges to issue warrants under part VI and the extent to which nominated AAT members are being used for that purpose—which would be available to the citizen to enable them to see whether or not these changes have, in fact, given law enforcement agencies a greater facility to detect the ever‐widening crime rate.
