SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition has a number of concerns about the Airports Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 . It is omnibus legislation which deals with a number of issues. Two or three of the proposals are quite unexceptional, and the opposition has no reservations about them. However, there are two matters to which we intend to move amendments. If those amendments are not successful, we will then oppose the legislation. There is also a further matter which we will seek to insert by amendment which I will refer to later.

SPEECH.PARA: The first of the major concerns of the opposition relates to the proposal to sell the remaining general aviation airports and two of the smaller RPT airports by freehold rather than long-term leasehold. That applies to Jandakot, Essendon, Moorabbin, Parafield, Archerfield and prospectively to Bankstown, Camden and Hoxton Park, including Tennant Creek and Mount Isa, which are not just general aviation airports.

The former Keating government introduced legislation to enable the sale of long-term leaseholds not only for the major airports, such as Melbourne and Sydney, but also for other FAC airports, such as the ones that I have just listed. It is important to note that what is occurring now is quite different from the local ownership program of airports that was put in place in the mid‐80s by the former Labor government. A very substantial number of smaller airports around the country were sold to public sector bodies—to local councils, port authorities and the like.

What is proposed in this legislation is to enable the federal government to sell these quite important airports freehold to private operators and to shift the planning control with respect to those airports to state governments. The federal government would retain a variety of functions with respect to the operations of those airports, such as those currently carried out by Airservices and the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. It is interesting to note that the expressions from the various state governments so far on this proposal have either been indifferent or negative.

It is perhaps understandable that the Victorian government would be rather concerned about this proposal. If this legislation is passed, it may mean that Jeff Kennett, rather than simply throwing bombs from the sidelines on the fraught question of the future of Essendon airport, will have to make the decision himself and deal with the concerns of the National Party in his own state. The Victorian government is totally split on the question of the future of Essendon airport. At the moment he can wash his hands of the issue and allow the federal government to make the decision. Therefore, it is not totally surprising that the Victorian government does not appear to be widely excited about this proposal.

Leaving aside any desires that any of us may have to solve Mr Kennett's political problems, which is certainly not high on my priorities, there are good reasons for the House to reject this proposition. It is important to recall that the airport sales legislation which the former government put to this parliament and which was eventually adopted by the current government was based on long-term leasehold. It ensures there is some degree of residual Commonwealth control or residual Commonwealth influence in the conduct of the business of airports that will occur in these particular locations.

It is true that the proposed sale would contain a caveat that the airport usage continue, but it means that the regulatory role that the Commonwealth plays would shift to the states. It is noteworthy that the sale legislation that was put to the parliament by us and adopted pretty much intact by the current government would therefore see a substantial part of that regulatory activity shift to the states. I think that would be detrimental to the aviation industry in this country. It would be detrimental to the operations of a number of those airports which operate on an interstate basis. Both Moorabbin and Essendon, for example, host services to Tasmania.

It would mean that there would be an unduly parochial focus in the planning regulation of those airports. It would also mean that one of the major developments that has occurred in recent times at a number of those airports—pilot training and export pilot training, including Parafield, which is in the electorate of the honourable member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans), who is at the table—would be occurring under the auspices of different state governments.

You would not have the same degree of national focus that you currently have in encouraging, assisting and providing for what is going to become and is already a very significant export for Australia. It is a classic area in which we have significant competitive advantage, and the federal government should be doing everything it can to assist in the growth of this very worthwhile industry. It will not help if we end up with a mixed regulatory regime in these airports, where we have state governments intruding and having to play a role which could ultimately be at odds with the objectives that we have as a nation to develop the pilot training industry and a whole range of detailed issues.

It is also rather peculiar that we will end up in a situation where we have mixed state and federal regulation on major airports. It probably does not matter a great deal to have small local airports with state planning regulatory activities and organisations like CASA still responsible for safety, but it does for major airports with significant RPT functions and very substantial numbers of movements. In fact, even though it entails training and the figure is slightly distorted, these airports have the largest number of movements of any airports in the country. We will end up with a mixed regulatory structure, which is not a good recipe for the future of aviation at that level in this country.

The opposition opposes this proposal. We supported the leasehold arrangements and we continue to support that arrangement, but we do not believe there is any justification for moving to an outright privatisation; a sale of the freehold of these airports.

The opposition is opposed to the second substantial proposal in this legislation to remove decisions of the minister with respect to airport master plans, environment strategies and the like from the jurisdiction of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It is proposed instead that these decisions would be the subject of a tabling in the House and, therefore, would ultimately be subject to judicial review.

The opposition believes that this is a substantial diminution of the rights of people in the community who are affected by airport operations, particularly those who live near airports and have a deep and intense interest in things like the contents of airport master plans. They should have every conceivable right to pursue those interests through the process of law and through the process of government to ensure that they get a fair deal.

This legislation diminishes those rights. There is no way around it: this legislation substantially diminishes those rights because the alternatives that will now be available to them will be more complex, more expensive and more difficult compared with the AAT.

This position was not adopted by the government before the last election. It was not announced in the debate prior to the airports sales legislation or, indeed, the sale of the airports themselves. In effect, it is a free kick for the new owners of the major airports at the expense of people living near and around those airports.

It means, for example, that when Sydney airport is ultimately sold, the rights of those people who currently suffer the consequences of the airports' operations, and in particular the bizarre flight path arrangements that were introduced by the former minister for transport, Mr Sharp, will be diminished as a result of this legislation. The opposition does not support that proposal. We will endeavour to amend the legislation to remove it. If we are unsuccessful, we accordingly will oppose the legislation.

The second reading speech really does not tell you precisely what is going on here. It seems that there even is a little bit of embarrassment about what the government is proposing to do. It is very elliptical about the concept of the proposal. It is noteworthy that the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) in his second reading speech referred to the tabling requirements as the new mechanism around which all the rights of local people would rotate. He said that these would apply `except to the extent that the commercial interests of a person would be substantially prejudiced'.

So good old commercial confidentiality rears its ugly head again. I have no doubt that the implications of that statement are that local groups seeking to pursue their rights on issues of pollution and aircraft noise, or whatever the case may be, will bump into that problem on numerous occasions. That is a good illustration of why maintaining the AAT rights of people who are affected by the operations of these airports is very important.

If you look around the country, you will see that these issues are already there. Only recently I was in Perth having discussions with the new owners of Perth airport about the prospective amendments to the master plan to include the possibility of an extension of the cross‐runway, which would have enormous implications for residents immediately to the west of the airport.

In Brisbane there is the prospect of a parallel runway, which equally raises substantial concerns for many people there. In Sydney a very wide range of issues arises from the operations of the airport and will cause immense problems for many people there. These are existing, here and now issues right around the country. The regulatory regime that was put in place by the Labor government, which was balanced, fair and which gave local residents a fair go—it was not finally legislated because it was blocked in the Senate and then was adopted by the new government with the support of the Labor opposition—is now being eroded. We do not accept that.

It is also worth noting in this context that there is another reason for opposing this: the ground rules for these airports are being changed after the sale. It is probably not a huge change when you are talking about many millions of dollars on the sale price. It probably would not have affected the price a great deal had the tenderers known at the time that there would be a new regulatory regime without the AAT involved.

Nonetheless, there is an important principle here. It is a principle that the Premier of Victoria does not appear to recognise because the legislative requirements for the casino in Victoria were changed four times after the completion of the tendering process and the granting of the tender to Hudson Conway and the Crown Casino.

I concede this is not in that league. Nonetheless it is a significant benefit to the successful tenderers and something that I think those who were unsuccessful probably would have liked to have known about prior to putting in their bids and having them judged. For that reason also we have very serious reservations about this proposal.

The final position that the opposition wishes to advance with respect to this legislation relates to restrictions on cross‐ownership of airports. Under the coalition this has been something of a moveable feast. When the airport sales legislation was being dealt with by the parliament in the middle of last year, the former minister for transport got a phone call from Richard Court probably about 12 hours before the legislation was going to be dealt with in the parliament. Mr Court told him that he wanted Perth to be in the cross‐ownership rules, that he wanted restrictions on Perth being owned by other major airport owners and that he wanted equal treatment for Brisbane and Melbourne, which is what the original cross‐ownership rules applied to.

Lo and behold! With no warning or announcement to anybody, and with no discussion, Perth was included. The opposition accepted that. We said, `Fine. We do not have any problems with that.' But, if you want Richard Court to run the country, why not get him up here, get him elected and put him in charge?

The government has now come up with another proposal on cross‐ownership, which was announced recently. Again it was out of the blue. But it was a Clayton's cross‐ownership proposal. With respect to Adelaide and Melbourne, Hobart and Launceston, Coolangatta and Brisbane, cross‐ownership would be banned—you cannot own both—for a period of two years. This would be enforced through the sale contracts.

This is purely a Clayton's cross‐ownership restriction. It effectively amounts to a government commitment not to sell the airports to the same owner. Two years is a pretty short time in the life of a new airport owner. It is unlikely that any owner of any of these airports is going to go to all the trouble of the tendering process, the investment and the pain and difficulty that that involves, and then sell within two years. In effect, all this is is the government saying, `We will sell Hobart and Launceston to different owners.'

The opposition supports that. What we are unhappy with is that, unlike the cross‐ownership restrictions that apply with respect to Melbourne, Brisbane vis-a-vis Sydney and, at the last minute, Perth, the government does not propose to legislate these cross‐ownership restrictions. There are good reasons why Adelaide airport should not be owned by the owner of Melbourne airport. There are good reasons why Coolangatta should not be owned by the owner of Brisbane. There are good reasons why Hobart and Launceston should be owned by different owners.

We therefore think that if the government is serious we should insert those cross‐ownership restrictions in the legislation and, in addition, insert the one city, the one airport, that stands out as the one that should have been in the cross‐ownership restrictions, given that they are being extended, and for some peculiar reason was left out—that is, Townsville. Townsville airport should not be owned by the owners of Brisbane, and it should not be owned by the Cairns Port Authority, which owns Cairns airport and which has done an excellent job of running Cairns airport.

BREAK.PARA: The airports at Townsville, Launceston and Hobart should be owned by local interests—those that have the interests of their local regional economy at heart, those that are tuned to those interests, those that are going to have their primary investment focus on that airport, those that are not going to see it as a poor relation and just there to keep the metre ticking over, to keep the till ticking over, but who see it as their primary focus.

There are many subtle issues that will emerge in the administration of those airports. Local interests will be of considerable importance where the synergies that can emerge from the conjunction between local business interests, the local community, local government and the owners and operators of that airport will have a significant impact on the local community, and where absentee ownership potentially may not be as good. The differences might be at the margins but, nonetheless, they will be significant. Cairns is a good example, where local ownership has been of considerable benefit to the Cairns economy.

By ensuring that we have cross‐ownership restrictions and that they are enshrined in legislation, we will guarantee that there will be a maximum degree of competition between those airports where competition can occur. Clearly, there are limits on that. But in the cases of Brisbane and Coolangatta there is considerable potential for competition. That possibility should be maximised. In the cases of Townsville and Cairns, there is already significant competition between those two cities on a variety of fronts. We should not have a situation where their airports are owned by the same owner and, therefore, in effect, are not competing.

Equally importantly, we want to ensure that the investment focus, the operational focus of these airports, has the local community and local regional economic interests paramount and not other interests. When you are marketing an airport, clearly you have to market a destination. Now that these will be private sector bodies seeking to attract flights, those who own them will be marketing the destination. If you own Townsville airport and are trying to get more planes to fly there you will not only be saying, `We have a wonderful airport,' but also be saying, `We have a wonderful city here. We have a wonderful region. We have reasons for people to come here.' Therefore, the nexus between the ownership of the airport and that local regional community is extremely important.

It is true that ownership restrictions potentially diminish price, but it is also worth noting a couple of things. Firstly, the government, when it was in opposition, did make certain commitments, which it now appears to have reneged on, with respect to local ownership in areas such as Launceston. That is something that we in government were committed to and something we remain firmly committed to.

Secondly, the price return on the sale of the major airports was so far in excess of expectations that surely the government can afford to take a marginal reduction in price for airports that, ultimately, are not going to command huge dollars anyway. In order to ensure that the local regional economies in areas like Launceston, which desperately need more investment and more economic activity, get the best economic outcome, surely the federal government in the context of its total airport sales program can afford to get slightly below the optimal or the maximum price in order to benefit the local communities that those airports serve.

For those reasons, when the matter returns from the Main Committee to the House and is considered in detail we will be moving a range of amendments that refer to the matters I have outlined today. If those amendments are unsuccessful—because we regard these issues as being of considerable seriousness—we will be opposing the legislation.

The major GA airports and those two RPT airports should not be freeholded. They should remain within Commonwealth jurisdiction. They should be leased in the same way that the other airports are being leased to private operators. The AAT should continue to have the power to scrutinise ministerial decisions with respect to airport master plans and environment strategies so that those affected by airport operations have a maximum degree of capacity to pursue their interests within the law, within the legal framework and within the framework of government. Finally, the cross‐ownership restrictions that the government has put forward should be strengthened and inserted in the legislation so that they have the full force of the law, and they should be extended to Townsville.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It comes as no surprise to Labor that we are now back here in this chamber—some 14 months after the government announced its measure to apply an additional 15 per cent tax on the superannuation contributions of high income earners—about to debate a large package of bills which will supposedly fix the many problems associated with the government's ill-conceived 15 per cent superannuation tax.

SPEECH.PARA: What can I say? We told you so. By `we', I do not just mean the opposition. It would unquestionably have been easier for the government to defend its position if it had been a simple case of Labor opposition to the policy. But the crowd of people lined up to tell the government how hopeless its collection method for the superannuation tax was would have been big enough to fill the great southern stand at the MCG. We had the Business Council of Australia, the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia, the large accounting firms, Coopers and Lybrand and William M. Mercer, the AMP Society, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants and the Institute of Actuaries of Australia.

It is not as if all of those industry organisations would be losers as a result of the government's collection method. On the contrary, some of them stood to benefit greatly from a more complicated collection method. Accountants and actuaries, for example, would have had more work created for them by the government's measure. One might think that groups who stood to benefit from the convoluted superannuation tax collection method would not speak out against it, let alone actually propose a simpler collection method which may result in less business coming in. But Coopers and Lybrand, William M. Mercer, the AMP Society, the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants and the Institute of Actuaries of Australia did just that. In the end, out of sheer exasperation, they were screaming loudly like an AFL crowd on grand final day about the many problems that the government would encounter if it chose to persist with its error‐riddled collection method.

Despite the advice offered the last time we debated these bills, despite the willingness and encouragement of the opposition for the government to change its method of collection of the superannuation tax, here we are again debating a set of bills designed to fix the government's superannuation tax mess.

I need to say right at the outset that the opposition will not be opposing this legislation because we believe that it is an attempt by the government to fix its superannuation tax mess. We believe that the government should—indeed, has an obligation to—clean up its own superannuation tax mess. However, we do have some concerns about these bills and the potential impact they may have. We will be supporting a reference of the package of bills to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation for comprehensive analysis and full public hearings as to the implications of these amendment bills. In addition, my colleague the member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis), the shadow minister for defence, will be moving some amendments relating to the way the superannuation tax applies to the military superannuation schemes and also some other measures to do with military superannuation which Labor believes are appropriate and which Labor has already announced publicly.

This is an appropriate place and time to remind the Australian public exactly why the government needs to re-visit the superannuation tax legislation and some of the problems these bills purport to fix. These bills are designed to ensure that the superannuation tax applies to those not already covered by the previous legislation due to legislative errors or due to constitutional bars.

The bills fall into three broad categories. The first is the application of the superannuation tax to defined benefit funds, to members of constitutionally protected superannuation funds—they are primarily the state based funds of Western Australia and South Australia—and to Commonwealth public sector superannuation funds, civilian, military, judicial and parliamentary. The second category is consequential amendments resulting from the application of the superannuation tax to the above funds. The third category is technical amendments to existing legislation arising out of previous Senate amendments to the superannuation tax bills.

The government did not intend in its initial legislation that certain funds and fund members would be excluded from having to pay the superannuation tax, despite being told that this would happen on numerous occasions. However, the complexity of the collection method and the initial legislation and also some constitutional uncertainties did, in fact, exclude some superannuation funds.

Why was the collection method the government chose so complex and so subject to constitutional uncertainty? The answer is quite simple and quite damning. To collect the superannuation tax in a way which was administratively the simplest and most cost effective would have meant breaking solemn commitments made before the last federal election not to raise the rate of existing taxes nor to introduce any new taxes, but that is exactly what this is—a new tax. That is the real reason why we are here again today considering the bills before the House—because the government made a promise before the last federal election which it broke immediately following that election.

How did the government deal with the fact that it was breaking its promise not to introduce any new taxes and not to increase existing taxes? It tried to deceive the Australian public by implementing what it called a surcharge but which everyone in the country knew was really another tax. It tried by sleight of hand to slip a new tax on superannuation past the people of Australia, calling it a surcharge and hoping nobody would notice. Well, people did notice. They noticed and they do not like being deceived. They are not impressed by governments who try to disguise broken election promises with the sophistry of calling a tax a surcharge. It did not work anyway. The superannuation tax which the government tried to hide by calling it a surcharge is now called a tax because of Labor's amendments in the Senate, which were designed to inject some honesty into the debate and to give the government the opportunity to go back to the drawing board and design a better collection method for the tax.

So the government could have saved us and itself a lot of trouble in the first place by calling the surcharge a tax and administering it in the most efficient manner possible, rather than in the error ridden manner which it chose. Of course, the government has shown that it is pretty good at hiding its taxation commitments. We all remember Mr Howard's pre‐election statements about a GST not being on the Liberal Party's policy agenda now or in the future, but we know that it is now back on the agenda and we know that as a result people who presently do not have to pay tax on food, on clothing, on services such as haircuts or on visiting sports fixtures will now be expected to pay a tax of the order of perhaps 15 per cent in order that others who are paying luxury taxes—who are already well‐to‐do—can pay less in luxury taxes and less in income taxes.

What exactly are the errors in the superannuation tax which these bills are purporting to fix? It seems to me that there are at least 10 bungles in the initial superannuation tax, and I want to take the House through them. The first is that the superannuation tax did not apply to state politicians, judges and public servants because they are in constitutionally protected schemes. The government was hoping to get the states to pass complementary legislation which would have allowed the tax to be collected from state public servants, judges and politicians but, unfortunately, that has not gone as hoped.

Watching this in action, I have got to wonder how the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) is going to go with his uniform retail tenancy code. He came into the House recently and said that he was going to fix up the problems of retail tenants but, when you looked at what he actually intended to do, you could see it was to go back to the states and get them to agree to matching complementary legislation around the nation. I certainly hope, for the sake of the retail tenants of this nation, that the small business minister goes very much better than the Treasurer (Mr Costello) did with his complementary legislation to allow the super tax surcharge to be collected from state public servants, judges and politicians.

Because of the failure of the government to get the cooperation of the states, we have here as part of this package two additional bills which will have the superannuation tax apply to these fund members. True to form with this superannuation tax, the way that the government is proposing to do this will create even further complexity, confusion and uncertainty for both superannuation funds and the fund members affected. Like the superannuation tax collection method for schemes which are not constitutionally protected, superannuation funds will be required to notify the Australian Taxation Office of a member's taxable superannuation contributions. However, for constitutionally protected schemes, it will be the fund member who is liable for the superannuation tax, rather than the superannuation fund itself. This, of course, differs from schemes which are not constitutionally protected, where the superannuation fund itself is liable for the superannuation tax.

It is important to remember that one of the reasons the government claimed its superannuation tax was not a tax was that it said the superannuation funds will be paying it, not the individual member. But, for constitutionally protected schemes, the opposite will be happening. So the government's feeble defence that it was not breaking an election promise now stands completely exposed.

The second bungle in the superannuation tax legislation was the government's failure to include federal public servants, judges and politicians. It is amazing to think that the government came up with a policy which did not include its own employees. One would have thought that the government would have been able to at least ensure that its own employees set an example by paying the tax.

The third bungle was the government's admission that it would have to redraft the legislation to correct problems in collection from the defined benefit funds. This problem arose from the government's attempt to make the legislation fit within the constitution after Dennis Rose QC pointed out that the tax was unconstitutional. The government's subse quent change to the legislation altered the definition of contributed amounts and excluded some defined benefit funds from having to notify the Australian Taxation Office of a member's surchargeable contributions. This became a wider problem when one considers that many so‐called accumulation funds could actually be considered as defined benefit funds in certain circumstances.

The fourth bungle related to evidence suggesting that the tax could be an eligible tax deduction. It is absolutely absurd that a tax, which is intended to raise revenue for the government, could be considered as a tax deduction, therefore negating the whole value of the exercise.

The fifth bungle relates to concerns that, in defined benefit funds with benefit cliffs, individuals could be assessed as having a total superannuation tax liability of higher than 15 per cent. The government seems to have understood the unfairness of the impact of this measure and has now apparently moved to ensure that does not happen.

That makes five bungles which this package of bills is proposing to rectify. The disappointing aspect of the next five concerns—or bungles—that I will identify is that they are errors in the government's model which no amount of legislative tinkering will adequately fix. The only way the government could fix the mess it has created would be to change the entire foolish collection method it adopted. For example, the government's legislative amendments are, unfortunately, too late to prevent rises in fees and charges as superannuation funds put in place ridiculously complicated systems to collect and process the information needed to pass on to the Australian Taxation Office. That is bungle No. 6. The estimated collection costs could be up to $100 million. Then there is the huge cost to superannuation funds of having to collect thousands of tax file numbers from members who, for their own reasons of privacy, may have chosen not to give their tax file numbers to their superannuation funds.

A perspective on the government's cost bungle is offered by Noel Davis, a partner with Clayton Utz, solicitors, who has followed the technical details of the government's superannuation tax closely. Mr Davis wrote this in a recent Superannuation Bulletin article:

Because of the deficiencies and complexities of the legislation imposing this tax . . . the cost of implementing the administration systems to collect the tax will probably exceed the amount of the revenue received by the Government from it.

That is absolutely incredible. The cost of implementing the superannuation tax collection system could exceed the revenue the government receives from it. Why? Because of the deficiencies and complexities of the legislation, according to Mr Davis, who is an expert in superannuation law.

What the government clearly does not care about is that, as superannuation funds pass on these added collection costs to fund members by increasing fees and charges, those increases will disproportionately affect low and middle income earners. In other words, government claims that this is a tax on higher income earners, those earning over $70,000, are false. Lower and middle income earners will be paying higher fees and charges in order that the government can collect it. So much for the government's claims in its budget boasts last year that it was attacking the top end of town.

Bungle No. 7 is the revelation that up to one million lower and middle income earners would have to pay the tax. This will occur because of the fact that those who do not provide their tax file number to their superannuation fund will be liable for the tax regardless of how much money they earn. What that means is that many low and middle income earners will in fact pay the superannuation tax. Just to check on whether that would be the case, one of the opposition staff rang the Australian Taxation Office yesterday to ask what would happen if he did not provide his tax file number to his superannuation fund. Would he have to pay the superannuation tax? The answer was yes, he would have to pay the superannuation tax if he did not provide his tax file number to the superannuation fund.

I have noticed the public advertising campaign that the Australian Taxation Office is running at the moment asking people to give their tax file numbers to their superannuation funds, using the slogan `Don't make an expensive mistake'. The irony in using a slogan like that is that it is the government that has made the expensive mistake. It will be interesting to find out from the Australian Taxation Office in the upcoming round of estimates hearings exactly how expensive the government's mistake is. I would imagine that advertising of the character that we are now seeing with the tax file number campaign does not come cheaply.

The eighth bungle in the government's superannuation tax collection method, which this legislation also will not remedy, is the constitutional problem. The House may recall the claims by Denis Rose QC that the new tax was illegal, particularly noting the fact that existing judges would have to be exempt. The question mark over the constitutionality of this tax can only be finally resolved by legal challenge.

The ninth bungle relates to actuarial concerns about the guidelines for assessing the tax liabilities of individuals in the defined benefit funds. This one will also be ongoing. Some actuaries have already indicated that they will be unable to prepare some individuals' tax liability assessments in time for superannuation funds to meet the government's 15 December deadline for reporting to the ATO. This is a matter of considerable concern. The government announced back in August last year that the superannuation tax was coming, yet we still have a situation where people in defined benefit funds are unable to know just what the impact of these changes will be on their superannuation entitlements as the 15 December deadline approaches. As we come towards a year and a half after the government first announced these changes, it is simply not good enough that people in these funds are unable to ascertain what their superannuation situation actually will be.

The actuaries are also concerned that, because of the nature of the calculations they are being asked to prepare, they may be personally liable if they overestimate an individual's tax liability. Again, this problem arises as a result of the government's chosen method to collect the superannuation tax.

The tenth bungle is the inequitable tax treatment of golden handshakes depending on whether they are taken as cash or are rolled over. This is something which the Labor opposition has raised with the government previously in Senate estimates, as indeed has one of the government's own members, Senator John Watson, who, as the House may be aware, has expressed great concern about the impact of the superannuation tax.

So there we have it: 10 commandments, 10 superannuation tax bungles, of which this legislation will fix only five. It would be nice to think that it would stop there but, with the complexity of these provisions, I am not so sure. Unfortunately, no amount of fiddling will fix a bad policy which regrettably appears to have caused a decline in confidence in the entire superannuation system.

Labor has worked hard since 1983 to build Australia's enviable three pillars retirement income system, of which superannuation is a crucial component. Over the period when Labor was in government, there was an enormous change in focus given to superannuation saving as part of the government's retirement income policy objectives. It was Labor which positioned superannuation to make a major contribution towards achieving our national savings objectives over the medium term. By any measure, our achievements were quite remarkable. We overwhelmingly succeeded in our objective of extending access to superannuation benefits throughout the work force, especially to women and part‐time employees, who previously were largely excluded. When we assumed office in 1983, only about 40 per cent of workers had any form of superannuation. Today the figure is around 90 per cent. It was Labor which established the foundations for a progressive improvement in the level of superannuation saving through the superannuation guarantee, and hence progressive improvements in end benefits upon retirement.

It was Labor which put in place a strengthened prudential regime through the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 which provides all of us with greater confi dence that the benefits promised by superannuation saving will in fact be realised. The end result of Labor's superannuation policies will be substantially higher incomes in retirement for ordinary workers. That is why it is particularly galling to see that good work being undone through bad policy and a lack of vision from a government which has no commitment to superannuation and which neglects our future. We have had a great deal of rhetoric from this government about debt and deficit. We all remember the debt truck and all those lines—`stealing from our children, mortgaging our future'. What on earth are these attacks on superannuation, if not stealing from our children, mortgaging our future, whittling away our capacity as a nation to provide for our own future?

The government's collection method for the superannuation tax is bad policy. Only the government believes that it is not bad policy. I have said that the opposition will not be opposing this legislation because it does represent an attempt by the government to fix some of its 10 superannuation tax bungles. However, given the complex nature of this entire issue and the uncertainty and confusion which surround the superannuation tax in general, we will be supporting a reference of the package of bills to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation for comprehensive analysis and full public hearings as to the implications of these amendment bills. We will be moving specific amendments in the area of military superannuation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly, Jackie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker Kelly, may I congratulate you on your recent appointment. It is the first time I have actually spoken before you in this House. I congratulate the National Party on their foresight and their attitude towards women in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Rising tonight, I do have to support this particular bill because I had supported quite strenuously the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge (Assessment and Collection) Bill 1997 on 20 March this year. This government is committed to the same standards for all. It is not a matter of having double standards; it is a matter of setting very high standards and applying them across the board. We have done that successfully on numerous occasions right throughout our time in government. Tonight is yet another example of that. Certainly someone in a superannuation scheme that does not receive employer contributions such as those funded out of consolidated revenue was in a position for a windfall gain in terms of not paying the costs which the entire society has been requested to pay at some stage for the excesses of the last 13 years.

That was unbeknownst to us. In funding any of our election promises we had assumed, as we had been told, that the budget was squared away. In fact we knew already that we had $17 billion‐odd to pay back on previous years overexpenditure. The last five years of the Keating administration saw Australia go heavily into debt.

We had to turn that around. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis, Ralph, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) has said, the opposition does not oppose these measures. It recognises the essentiality of them. Given that we already have the superannuation contributions tax, it would be most inequitable not to apply it to everyone at the income levels at which it is supposed to apply. Obviously, for the people in defined benefit schemes—the constitutionally protected schemes—not to be affected by it would be inequitable, and therefore we support it.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I would like to make some general points. Firstly, if I could just make a point about the budget for the benefit of the honourable member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly). When this party left government the budget deficit figure, even on the $10 billion figure always used by the then opposition and now government, still gave Australia a budget position which was better than that of almost any European country. It would easily have qualified for the Euro‐currency provisions by an amount which is about two per cent of GDP budget deficit when the limit they have set is three per cent—and they are all battling to meet it even now. So the budget position that we left this country when we went out of government was better than that of virtually any country in Europe except Luxembourg. Let us get that on the record. This nonsense about how we left some terrible, disastrous budgetary position is just that—absolute nonsense.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to refer to a number of general factors about the measure before us, the superannuation contributions tax. Firstly, as has been mentioned by the member for Wills, it is a clear breach of the election promise of no new taxes and no increase in any tax made by the now Treasurer (Mr Costello) time and time again before the last election. That promise is completely broken by this measure. On page 11 of their published superannuation policy, it was said:
Taxation: A Coalition Government will retain the current taxation treatment of superannuation . . .

It went on to talk about how the RBLs were a good form of defining the basis for tax support. The superannuation contributions tax as it is now known—not the `surcharge' as they tried to call it at first—is a complete breach of the coalition's election promise not to introduce any such tax.

Secondly, this clear breach of an election promise comes in addition to another absolutely clear breach of an election promise: to implement the previous government's superannuation policy in relation to co‐contributions for employee contributions. That involved using the second leg of the tax cuts to provide matching contributions for employees, subject to a means test. The then coalition opposition, now government, promised the Australian people faithfully that they would implement that policy if they were elected. That policy has now been completely and utterly broken. It is a $4 billion breach of promise—a spectacular breach of promise. You promised to give people $4 billion and then you do not do it. It is not just some minor event that we are talking about here; it is an extraordinary breach of promise. On top of that you impose a tax of half a billion dollars that you said you would not introduce. This government has no credibility whatsoever in this area.

Thirdly, because of their sensitivity about breaking their election promise not to introduce any new taxes, the government have foisted an incredibly cumbersome and expensive administrative arrangement on employers, superannuation funds and the Australian Taxation Office. They are doing that because of the subterfuge that they went through over the surcharge—`We will put a surcharge on the funds, we will say that is not a tax and, therefore, we will not be breaking our election promises.' That subterfuge has been blown away by the amendments in the Senate. The surcharge is now described as a tax. It is unambiguously clear that we have a tax, but the nightmare administrative arrangement which the surcharge involved remains; in fact, it becomes more nightmarish as we see the detail for dealing with unfunded schemes where there is no annual contribution to tax. You have a superannuation contributions tax on funds where there is no contribution so you have to make one up.

These superannuation bills are largely about making up a basis for a tax to apply to contributions where there are no contributions until the end benefits are payable. To do that, we have an incredibly cumbersome array of administrative arrangements, which I will mention later in some detail. I would like to note in passing that all this sits rather oddly with the promise faithfully made to the industry by the now Treasurer prior to the election that the superannuation policy of the coalition was one of `confidence, certainty and simplicity'. That is what he said they would bring to the industry. I would say that none of that exists as a result of this government's measures and of all the mucking around, particularly with the extraordinary administrative complexity of this tax which has foisted costs on the industry, reduced benefits and generally got the industry very off‐side—and rightly so.

Fourthly, I refer to the unfairness of this tax. It requires the tax file number of each contributor to be notified to their superannuation fund and then to the Taxation Office. If the member does not provide the tax file number, they are hit with the superannuation contributions tax, as the member for Wills explained. He mentioned that industry estimates are that up to a million people could be wrongly taxed. The ATO campaign, which is starting now, will hopefully reduce that number, but it would certainly seem that a lot of people are not going to understand the importance of this issue and are not going to furnish their tax file number. That is apart from the fact that, despite being low or middle income earners who should not be subject to this tax, they will be subject to it, which will mean that it is an unfair imposition on them.

Fifthly, we have the issue of driving high income earners out of superannuation. Only a mug with a high income or someone who has no alternative because they are compelled to contribute would bother contributing while there is this tax. There is simply not anything in it any more; it is just not fair. There is a marginal degree of tax concession, but for people with relatively high incomes that is a pretty small element to receive in return for tying their money up for decades and decades—and for what? For a concession that virtually does not exist!

Just look at the tax regime that currently exists, and will exist, with the superannuation contributions tax. For funded lump sums, we had a 15 per cent tax on contributions and a 15 per cent tax on earnings. The lump sum was tax free on the first $83,000, and then there was a 15 per cent tax on the lump sum over $83,000. So the tax level on the lump sum could be up near 30 per cent for lump sums well over $83,000. There was 15 per cent on the contributions and the earnings and 15 per cent on the end benefit, or near to it.

Now that goes up, with the superannuation contributions tax, to 30 per cent on the contributions and 15 per cent on the earnings. The lump sum is tax free on the first $83,000 and then attracts a tax of 15 per cent. So the tax level rises to near 45 per cent for large sums. That is almost at the top marginal tax rate—47 per cent, or 48.4 per cent with the Medibank levy. Why lock your money away for decades just to save 3 per cent? That is what people will be saying to themselves: `Why am I doing this? What is in it for just 3 per cent?' Even if it is for 4 per cent or 5 per cent, it is relatively little.

For superannuation pensions, the tax rate will now be over 60 per cent. For funded schemes, there was a 15 per cent tax on contributions and earnings. The tax on the pension was the marginal rate minus 15 per cent—that reflects the 15 per cent paid on the contributions and earnings—so the total tax was at the marginal rate. Now, with the SCT, there is 30 per cent tax on the contributions, 15 per cent tax on the earnings, taxed on the pension at the marginal rate minus 15 per cent, so the total is near to 63 per cent. There is 30 per cent on the contributions and there is the top rate—48 per cent minus 15—which is 33 per cent. So you are talking about marginal tax rates on a pension of about 63 per cent.

Why would you put your money into a superannuation scheme to pay a 63 per cent tax rate? Why would you do it? The answer is that people are not going to do it. Anecdotal evidence certainly is that they are not doing it. It will take a while to see the hard impact of that, because it will take time for people to unwind arrangements and salary packages, et cetera. But I am sure that we will see a lot of high income earners walking away from this area of saving, and understandably so. They will put their money where it has a better tax concession. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) says he will keep negative gearing, so people will stick their money in there, or they will put it somewhere else—into the family home or somewhere—where it is not going to attract tax rates which are at, near or above the top marginal tax rate.

This also comes with a potential impact on savings. If high income earners are not going to put their money into superannuation, they may put it into another savings device or they may not. They may just squander it in some way or other, which is clearly not good for national savings.

So the superannuation contributions tax in general is an incredibly poor piece of policy to address a perceived inequity in superannuation. Labor's approach was much better. What we proposed—and what the coalition said that they would introduce and then broke their promise on—was a policy which improved the equity of the superannuation system considerably. What it did, with the matching contributions being means tested, was to make sure that the $4 billion of matching contributions—when it was fully phased in—all went to low and middle income earners. And higher income earners—that is, those receiv ing over twice average weekly earnings—got nothing. Had that system been introduced, this clearly would have improved the equity of the superannuation system considerably. Now that that promise has been broken—it is not being introduced, and we have this tax instead—we have a rather less equitable arrangement.

And we also have a greater impact on savings, because the scheme we were going to introduce would have added 1.7 per cent of GDP to savings eventually, according to the Treasury retirement income modelling task force. Without that, we do not get any of that benefit. What we get is this superannuation contributions tax, which cannot improve national savings, because it is taxing savings and taking them to another form of savings. It is taking from private savings to public savings; there is nothing going to national savings. But, in so far as it drives people away from that area of savings to squander their money, you have a net loss of savings, and that is basically what will come from this whole measure.What we have here could be said to be another form of SG. We have the superannuation guarantee, often abbreviated as the SG. Some people have said that this is certainly an SG—it is the spruce goose of the tax system.

The superannuation bills now before the House have tremendous complexity in terms of the way in which they go about trying to raise the tax, because they are trying to tax contributions that do not exist. For unfunded defined benefits schemes there are no contributions by employers to apply a superannuation contributions tax to, so these bills provide a means of inventing them. In the process, they develop a tangle of red tape which makes an utter joke of this government's promise to cut red tape by 50 per cent for small business and of its general approach of saying it is about cutting red tape.

I am not sure that time will allow me to go through this entirely, but, in brief, the process you have to go through is this. What happens in the case of defined benefits schemes is that, firstly, the tax applies if the adjusted taxable income is above $70,000, or, as adjusted, I think, $73,200 this year, and fully from $85,000, or, as adjusted, $88,900.

But, to find out what the adjusted taxable income is, one has to find out what the surchargeable contribution by the employer is, because it is not just your taxable income, it is your taxable income plus your surchargeable contribution by the employer. To find that out, one has to work out a notional surchargeable contribution factor; or at least actuaries have to work that out. The fund has to get the actuaries to do that. As the member for Wills said, the actuaries are unhappy about this process and about the position that they are being put into. The tax commissioner has had to issue a ruling to try to provide some basis for them to operate on, but they are concerned about the fact that there could be many complaints about the subjective decisions they have to make in working out this notional surchargeable contribution factor on which tax will be based.

Once we have that, the fund is required to notify the tax office of the surchargeable contribution. So you have got the surchargeable contribution being worked out on the basis of the notional surchargeable contribution factor being applied to the employer's contribution. That is notified to the tax office. The tax office calculates the member's adjusted taxable income, calculates the rate of surcharge that applies, if any, and makes an assessment of the surcharge payable.

Then the superannuation provider—that is, the fund—is required to maintain a surcharge debt account with annual assessments of the surcharge payable being added to that account. Interest has to be calculated on that account at the 10‐year bond rate. The contributor can pay the surcharge each year if they wish but, if not, it adds up year by year with interest.

When a person retires, there is a surchargeable debit in their account, and this has to be paid to the ATO before any lump sum is paid. But before one gets to that point, one has to have an assessment as to whether what is in the surchargeable debt account is actually the amount the contributor should pay. The board of trustees is required to determine, in writing, the surcharge deduction amount that it considers would be fair and reasonable, having regard to a number of factors. This is because the contributions that could have been paid by the employer over time might be too much or too little in relation to the end benefits being obtained by the member, and the board of trustees—extraordinarily—is put in the position of virtually deciding what the tax liability of this person is. The board of trustees is there to look after the member's interests, not to determine his tax bill, but this is what is happening here.

The board of trustees, the defender of the member of the fund, has to work out whether the amount that is in the surchargeable debt account is fair and reasonable. If it is too little, they have to increase it—to increase the member's tax. If it is too much, they reduce it. But it puts an onus on the board of trustees which I find quite extraordinary; indeed, a conflict of interest. Surely, their interest is to look after the member's fund interest as much as possible, not to work out his tax bill. The tax office should make that decision. This is just off‐loading the work onto the fund. This is a quite extraordinary development that has to look at all sorts of measures which I will not go into because of lack of time.

There is a cap of 15 per cent on the surcharge deduction amount, which is a good thing. If the end benefit is to be paid as a pension, then the board of trustees, on advice of its actuary, has to determine the conversion factor to work out the deduction from the pension that is required each year to pay off the surcharge debt. This calculation does not just use any conversion rate from pension to lump sum that might be in the fund. It has to work on a market rate, et cetera, and it is quite a complicated calculation.

So you have got all these expensive, costly steps which are adding cost to the system, and it is all avoidable. What the fund has to go through is just extraordinary, and I will not go through a summary of all that, but it could all have been avoided. If you want to increase the tax on people with high levels of superannuation, the simple thing to do would be to increase the tax on their end benefits—on their lump sum or their pension. But of course that would have been a tax, and that is why they would not do it. They said, `We are not taxing anybody, we are only surcharging the funds.'

Because we had this pretence that they were not breaking election promises, we have this extraordinary complexity which is increasing the cost for the funds enormously, reducing benefits for members because they have to wear those increased costs in terms of lesser benefits and unfairly impacting on a lot of people who should not be affected by it, who do not provide their tax file number.

This is a disastrous policy. It may well not raise anything like $500 million and, if it does, it will probably be because hundreds of thousands of people who should not be paying the tax are paying it. This is a total disaster of administration and it ought not to be continued. If the government wants to tax people at a higher level, it should do it in the simple way and not in this roundabout, absurd, costly way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In many respects this superannuation legislation is not especially controversial, but I must say that I found myself in tune with many of the criticisms of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), some of which I will touch on and some of which, I suspect, I raised when the principal act was being debated but which are still valid as expressed by the honourable member.

SPEECH.PARA: The intent behind the amendments in the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Superannuation Contributions Tax) Bill 1997 is to better align the statute regulating accounts held in unfunded, defined superannuation funds to those held in funded schemes. Any lack of symmetry is the direct result of the government's poor handling of the whole superannuation surcharge tax issue.

On 13 September 1997, in a review of the principal superannuation surcharge legislation, the Age newspaper said, `The government's superannuation surcharge on high income earners contains so many flaws that $250 million in expected revenue is at risk this year.' That comment was not particularly new, either. On the contrary, this was the very same argument raised by peak taxation organisations, including the Taxation Institute of Australia, at the time the parent legislation was introduced and debated in this parliament.

Had the coalition been prepared to take the time to consult widely with those who have the expertise, this follow‐up legislation would not have been necessary. Instead, it adopted a `take no prisoners' approach, the result being that valuable debating time has had to be allocated once again in this place to bring about changes that should have been incorporated in the original legislation.

One of the most serious deficiencies in the act was that it had little application to defined benefits funds. This bill amends nine existing acts so that public servants, new federal judges, federal members of parliament, the Governor‐General and Defence Force personnel are liable to pay the additional superannuation impost if their annual incomes exceed $70,000.

The proposed amendments will, amongst other things, guarantee that neither the termination payment surcharge nor the superannuation contribution surcharge is tax deductible. Such deductibility was never the intention of the government and the provision merely serves to close off a loophole that was overlooked in the original act. The bill also means to restrict the information relating to the details of surchargeable contributions that have to be forwarded by a provider to a fund member. As the Institute of Chartered Accountants has observed, prior to this amendment providers would have been required to give a copy of the whole statement to the member, including a mass of identifying material. It is my understanding that this amendment is not a concern to those in the superannuation industry.

In cases where the assessment of an individual's surcharge liability is reviewed and reduced, this bill will oblige the Australian Taxation Office to pay interest on the payment of the surcharge. That too is unobjectionable.

Because most of those affected by this legislation are members of either largely or fully unfunded defined schemes, there is no fund from which to pay the surcharge. Consequently, this bill provides members with the choice of paying the accumulated debt when they receive their superannuation benefit or paying the impost as it arises. It is a reasonable measure on the face of it; however, once again it brings to the fore the whole issue of unfunded liability and, specifically, the unfunded liability that will have to be met by the federal government in the future.

On 13 July 1996, Mr Michael Rice, Managing Director of MJR Consultants, spoke at the superannuation 1996 conference. He noted then that, as at March 1996, the public sector held between $80 million and $100 million in unfunded liabilities, most of which is a liability of the federal government. This figure will continue to sprout and will place a massive drain on future government revenues. In this climate of reform of the aged care and health systems, reforms which encourage individuals to take full responsibility for their own future whenever possible, it is reasonable to ask what the government intends to do to encourage savings schemes that are paid for in full by individuals.

I commenced by saying that this legislation is largely uncontentious; however, there is one provision that is of concern to the Institute of Chartered Accountants. That provision appears on page 2 of the explanatory memorandum and affects the application of the surcharge to the schemes provided for by this legislation. The explanatory memorandum reads, in part:
Trustees will have discretion to allow reductions to be applied in a fair and equitable manner, taking various matters into account.
It continues:
This discretion is necessary in cases where actual benefits are considerably more, or less, than the projected benefit on which the surchargeable contributions—
and therefore the surchargeable tax—
has been based.

The institute acknowledges that this bill ensures that a member's benefit for the surcharge cannot exceed 15 per cent of the employer financed component of the benefit accrued in the post‐August 1996 period. Nonetheless, this provision will cause a substantial inequity between the treatment of private sector and public sector superannuation funds.

BREAK.PARA: The ICA makes it clear that, in the case of a defined benefits scheme, which includes many public sector schemes, the contributions reflect a valuable retirement benefit. But if a member departs before he or she reaches retirement age, the member gets a much less valuable benefit. The measures in this bill grant trustees of public sector funds the discretion to accommodate any adjustment that may be required in the surcharge debt in this circumstance. This will give rise to an inequity because a trustee of a private sector fund does not have the same authority. In this instance, the member's benefit is protected, but it would not have been the case should a similar situation arise in the private sector.

To highlight this, I borrow from an example used by the Institute of Chartered Accountants, where an employer pays 10 per cent of a member's salary into an accumulated fund. This figure is above that which is required by the superannuation guarantee legislation, but the member must serve a minimum period before he or she gets the excess over that amount of six per cent. As the ICA observes:
The surcharge is based on the whole 10% but, until the minimum qualifying period is completed, the member's benefit is only the accumulation of (the superannuation guarantee) contributions.

The Institute of Chartered Accountants is also concerned by the lack of detail about how this discretion can be exercised. It is probable that the government intends for the surcharge debt to be calculated against the benefit that is actually paid, but this is not articulated either in the bill or in the explanatory memorandum. The ICA has indicated that this is a reasonable measure but only if the trustees of private sector funds have the same authority.

Another tax expert in Western Australia has questioned the lack of detail relating to items 63, 64 and 65 of the explanatory memorandum. These items impact on the deduction of a surcharge deduction amount from a transfer value payable to an eligible superannuation scheme. The explanatory memorandum reads:

If (a) person has a surcharge debt when leaving the scheme, the debt does not become payable until the benefits become payable. Interest will continue to accrue on the amount in the surcharge debt account, until that time.
However, there is no mention here about how a fair level of interest payable will be determined, and the member for Gellibrand touched on that.

This same tax expert has also questioned the decision to apply the additional 15 per cent tax to the benefits payable to the spouse or orphaned children following the death of a member of a superannuation fund. While the application of the impost may net the government a greater slice of the cake in the short term, it is questionable whether it will have any longer term benefits.

Criticism is also deserved about the lack of content in the financial impact statement in the explanatory memorandum and the total absence of a compliance impact statement. Back in November 1993, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts recommended:

. . . all future legislation be supported by a taxation impact statement, which details the impact on taxpayers of the legislation, including the total compliance cost, and the extent to which simplification objectives can be achieved.

As Messrs Evans and Walpole of ATAX at the University of New South Wales have noted, that recommendation was accepted by the government of the day on the basis that legislation should not bring about burdens beyond those that are acceptable and necessary. It was also supported by the then opposition. However, it would now seem that that support has been tempered during the transition to the right side of the chamber.

The total absence of a cost impact statement in this legislation is conspicuous for a number of reasons, not the least of which is that the coalition went into the last election with a commitment to reducing the regulatory burden on the business community. The government is fully aware of the significance of its impositions on taxpayers, and yet it has opted to reject the requirement to table an appropriate impact statement in this instance.

When the principal superannuation surcharge legislation was introduced into this place last year, tax experts agreed that the government's claims of a $500 million gain to revenue were grossly exaggerated. Perhaps the government now concedes that to be true, because the financial impact statement in this explanatory memorandum suggests that the surcharge tax legislation is intended to bring about an `increase in revenue', although no dollar amount is mentioned. So we have gone from a gain to revenue of $500 million to an unquantified increase in revenue.

The financial impact statement goes on to say that the amendments contained in this bill will support that intention; that means, it will provide an increase in revenue. But, once again, the figures that would give weight to the claim have been excluded. Presumably, the government is relying on this additional revenue to balance its books in future, although by what amount is just anybody's guess.

I acknowledged in August last year that it is difficult to quantify the costs of compliance for individual organisations. However, I also noted that, if a government is able to project the cost or gain to revenue, they should be able to estimate the compliance cost to the economy. In this case, it appears that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) cannot even estimate the effects on revenue. The fact that the trustees of those superannuation funds affected by the proposed measures will have to advise the Australian Taxation Office each financial year of the surchargeable contributions paid to the scheme for every member of that scheme will necessarily mean an increase in administration costs.

But the extent of their obligation goes further than that because, once the ATO has advised the trustee of the surcharge amount applicable to each member, the trustee must then pay that amount from the superannuation fund to the ATO and then make the necessary alterations to the member's account. Once again, the member for Gellibrand's criticisms stand. This will generate a substantial increase in the cost of compliance for the trustees, which will almost certainly translate into a cost on all members of funds, regardless of their income.
The time has come for the government to do what should already have been done—that is, substantiate this bill with a detailed cost and financial impact statement.

One issue that has been of ongoing concern to tax experts and consumers alike has been the treatment of golden handshakes being paid to staff. The original legislation would see the full amount of any such payment that is rolled over into a superannuation fund being subject to the additional superannuation impost. That could cost some individuals tens of thousands of dollars in lost benefits.

When the coalition first announced its intention to impose the surcharge, it justified its decision on the grounds that the additional tax would only apply to 300,000 high income earners nationwide. I said at the time that it was probable that many people not originally intended to be caught in its web would be affected by the tax. The application of the additional 15 per cent to golden handshakes is just one example. If the government is serious about fostering an equitable taxation regime, then it would have brought about measures in this bill to ensure that those who have provided for their own retirement are not penalised so comprehensively.

A secondary motivation behind the introduction of the surcharge was to force an increase in our level of national savings—a commendable objective. But it is ironic then that a recent survey by the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants is reported to have found that 47 per cent of the clients interviewed had reduced their superannuation contributions as a direct consequence of the surcharge. Just as alarming was the fact that 85 per cent of accountants surveyed were of the opinion that the coalition's treatment of superannuation had seen a serious decline in the integrity of the system.

Australians are not good savers. I said during the debate on the surcharge that home ownership would remain the preferred savings option for most Australians and that superannuation will not be used more than it has to be unless people have confidence in the system. The coalition's additional 15 per cent impost did nothing to shore up that sort of confidence; it did everything to rattle it. The measures contained in this bill will confirm in the public's mind that this government is no different to its predecessor when it comes to putting its hand in a very tempting cookie jar.
