TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move opposition amendments Nos 1 and 2:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Schedule 4, page 23, after item 39 (after line 6), insert:
39A Section 43 (at the at the end of proposed subparagraph (a)(ii) of the definition of adjusted taxable income )
Omit "and", substitute "or".
(2) Schedule 4, page 23, after item 39 (after line 6), insert:
39B Section 43 (at the at the end of proposed subparagraph (a) of the definition of adjusted taxable income )
Insert:
(iii) that were retention bonuses for members of the Australian Defence Force; and

These amendments are similar to the amendments that were moved in the Senate when the legislation was first presented in August, I think, to the Senate—the original first tranche of legislation dealing with the superannuation contributions and termination payments taxes legislation. The purpose of these amendments is to exempt from the calculation of income certain payments that are received by members of the Australian Defence Forces. These are payments that are received as retention bonuses.

Retention bonuses are made available to members of the services for very good reasons of requirement of the government. These are bonuses paid to people in the services to retain in the services skills that are in short supply and individual people who the services have determined are important to be retained. Those individuals are being asked to continue their service in the defence of Australia and, in consideration of their willingness to serve future years, are receiving a financial payment.

This government will, in the bill before the parliament—unless it is amended in the way I have proposed—include those payments as income, which will place virtually all of its recipients over the threshold above which the additional superannuation tax will be incurred. There is no justification for on the one hand asking service personnel to give extra years service and, on the other, hitting them about the head with an extra superannuation tax.

In the case of notably pilots in the RAAF and in Army, and also air traffic controllers, where there has been an acute shortage for some years, the government has actually gone out of its way to entice those people to stay on by offering them a special superannuation bonus. Having offered them a special bonus, it intends to slug their superannuation when they finally get it.

No advice is being given to people in the services about the effects on their superannuation of accepting the bonus. It is bad enough that the government is actually doing this, but what is absolutely underhanded is that the government is not even advising the service personnel that, if they do what the government asks them to do and stay on in the service of the defence forces, they are going to get hit with extra tax on their superannuation benefit, which for many people in the services is a fundamentally important condition of service.

They are not even being given the advice that their superannuation is going to be reduced if they agree to stay on. You have to ask yourself: how honest is that? You have to ask yourself: what would happen if the government actually came clean with those pilots, air traffic controllers and people in other key positions when they tell them, `You do what we ask you to do and stay on and fly a Hercules aircraft or an FA18 for us instead of going off to Qantas or Cathay Pacific and earning big buckets of money, because we want your special skills'? But the government keeps tight‐lipped about what it is going to do to their superannuation.

It is important to understand that these payments that the government is going to include which will take them over the threshold—which will reduce their superannuation payment because the government is going to grab extra tax from them—do not actually contribute to their superannuation benefit. Yes, they get a cash payment, they get a bonus with their income, but that bonus is not actually included to improve their superannuation benefit at all. So it is not as though it goes into their income calculation to boost their superannuation benefit and then you take a slice of that. They do not get any superannuation increase out of this money. What they get is extra tax imposed upon them, by virtue of this legislation which will strip away some of their superannuation benefits.

If the government is not willing to support these amendments, they should at least be honest and open with the defence personnel of Australia. When they say to them, `We want you to stay on and we will offer you a bonus,' they should at least be honest and open about it and say, `And, if you accept it, you will go over the threshold and incur an additional tax on your superannuation benefit.' (Extension of time granted)

A retention benefit is available also to those service personnel who are in the MSBS, which was introduced by the former Labor government in 1991. The scheme provides that people with 15 years service who undertake a further five years service also get a retention payment. That bonus is not given to them just for length of service; it is given to people selectively on the basis that they have skills to contribute that we want to retain. It is probably not as precise a bonus as the one I just referred to with air traffic controllers and pilots—which are the principal categories, but not the only categories.

The simple fact of life is that, in both situations, the government of the day and the chiefs of the defence services identify individuals who we want to retain. In just about every one of the cases they are individuals who have very marketable skills. The reason the government offers them a retention bonus to stay on is precisely that they have marketable skills that see them highly sought after by the private sector. There has been a drain in those key positions within the defence forces.

The government's approach of providing a retention bonus to keep pilots and air traffic controllers is at best a bandaid. As I have gone around the country, it has been interesting to note that one of the spin-offs is that some people who have not taken or been offered a bonus and who were happy to turn up at work beforehand are now quite disgruntled that their colleagues have been given this bonus and they have not. What you win with one hand you have actually lost with the other hand. The bonus scheme is at best a bandaid, short‐term measure. That is the kindest interpretation you can give to it.

The fact remains that the government provides a significant financial incentive to keep those people because they have very marketable skills that the private sector headhunts. If they agree to stay on in the service, this bill will impose upon them an additional 15 cent tax on their superannuation. Many of those people do not currently go over the $70,000 threshold; their wages are not that high. Some will, but many will not. It is precisely those people who you are going to slug with one hand as you try to entice them with the other.

People in the defence forces, particularly the ones we are talking about, are not stupid. They may not be aware of the pea and thimble trick you are playing on them in this legislation when they sign on. But one thing is certain: as they draw closer to their retirement from the services, they will become aware of it, and they will think back on the deception that you have perpetrated and will be very disgruntled long-term service personnel. There are enough problems with morale in the defence forces at the moment because of decisions that this government has taken and the ineptitude in a whole range of areas in terms of policy development and structural reform. That ineptitude is causing its own set of problems. If you proceed with this bill to compound that and to further reduce morale in the services, then I promise that you will not have to wait for them to reach retirement age because I will make sure that they know in advance.

I seek from the government, if it is not willing to support this amendment, a clear statement about its intentions as to the advice it will provide defence personnel—those who have already accepted a retention bonus and those they will offer the retention bonus to in the future. I seek from the government a clear commitment that they will provide full details to each of those individuals who is offered a retention bonus of the impact the acceptance of the retention bonus will have on their superannuation and, in particular, the impact this 15 per cent superannuation tax will have on them. In the course of the debate—if not in this chamber, then certainly in the Senate—I would appreciate a clear statement from the government on that important point of principle. I urge the House to support the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This aspect of superannuation in the armed forces is only one of a number of other complaints the opposition has with the current superannuation schemes affecting armed force personnel. In the light of the significant job losses that the government is condemning the armed forces to in the next few years from the defence efficiency review, we believe there are significant reasons now why there should be the possibility of those people having the option to choose between the defence force retirement and death benefit scheme or the military superannuation and benefit scheme. As well, there is the issue of the choice to rollover employer MSBS contributions into another fund if the person resigns or is discharged from the ADF.

SPEECH.PARA: They are issues the opposition has said should be on the agenda. They should be considered by this government. Quite frankly, it is very obvious that the minister involved has a studied disinterest in these matters despite their importance to the armed forces.

The genesis of this particular aspect is that in the 1996-97 budget the Treasurer (Mr Costello) announced that an additional tax would be imposed on `high income earners'. This impacts on people earning $70,000 or more and increases over the income range so that at the $85,000 level they pay the full 15 per cent additional tax. These income levels refer to the concept of adjusted taxable income, which is broadly defined to capture remuneration packaging arrangements which are commonly utilised by high income earners for tax minimisation purposes. It covers more than just a person's salary narrowly defined. It includes, for example, deductible employer superannuation contributions made for the employee's benefit.

In a cynical exercise, the government originally tried to describe the additional tax as a surcharge but has been forced to accept that this is a tax and that the relevant legislation is tax legislation. The original package of legislation imposing additional tax was passed earlier in the year with significant amendments being made by the Senate. Under the legislation, the additional tax became payable from budget night—20 August 1996.

It has now become apparent that the government's original legislation was replete with errors and anomalies. This further package of bills attempts to correct the more obvious of these. The proposals in these bills include the extension of the additional tax to defined benefits superannuation funds and to Commonwealth public sector superannuation schemes, including the military and a number of other areas.

Labor believes that the design of the additional tax is ill conceived. It supports, however, the need to address the anomaly whereby high income state and territory public servants, judges and politicians are not currently liable to pay the additional tax whereas other taxpayers on identical incomes do.

There are significant impacts on ADF personnel. A number of them will be subject to additional tax. The opposition does not propose a blanket exemption but wishes to correct design flaws in the government's package. These design flaws result from the coalition's failure to properly consider the unusual employment conditions associated with military service and its failure to consider the negative impact of its changes on efforts to improve the retention of skilled military personnel.

In 1991, the then Labor government introduced a retention benefit that is payable to personnel who have completed 15 years service with the ADF and who undertake to complete a further five years service. The benefit is paid as a lump sum bonus equal to the person's annual salary and is taxed as assessable income in the hands of the individual. Service personnel up to and including the rank of major—or equivalent—also receive an annual service allowance of $6,037 per annum which is included in their salary. A number of additional bonuses are provided to pilots and engineers and air traffic controllers, et cetera. As the member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) indicated, these are the kinds of people that this government supposedly were concerned about retaining in the defence forces rather than encouraging them to leave.

For reasons which I will detail, the opposition's amendment seeks to exempt ADF retention benefit and bonuses from the calculation of adjusted taxable income for the purposes of the additional superannuation tax. It is clear the retention benefit is not a salary packaging arrangement designed with tax minimisation purposes in mind. Since its introduction, it has always been counted as assessable income and is taxed at the appropriate marginal tax rate. As the shadow minister for defence has noted, the retention benefit does not increase the service person's end superannuation benefit.

The retention benefit was introduced to reduce the loss to the private sector of skilled military personnel who have been the beneficiaries of expensive taxpayer funded education and whose retention contributes to the protection of Australia's military preparedness. Whilst the benefit can be substantial and might be seen by some as generous, it is only given in return for a signed undertaking to undertake a further five years service. (Extension of time granted) Few other Australians are expected to contract to remain in an employer's service for five years and accept postings as and when the employer requires with associated disruptions to the employment of partners, changes to children's schooling and child care and often exposure to extremes of climate.

Another aspect of why we have concerns with this is that the Treasurer has said from the outset that the additional superannuation tax was only aimed at high income earners. Indeed, in his 1996 budget speech he said:
For superannuation contributors with such incomes below $70,000 per annum, there will be no change whatsoever.

However, by including ADF retention benefit and service allowance and definition of income, the Treasurer has ensured that the tax will be imposed on ADF personnel who cannot possibly be described as high income earners.

BREAK.PARA: I have no problem with the concept that a brigadier earning more than $85,000 a year should be subject to the additional tax, but let us look at some other examples involving the ADF. A sergeant in the army on the top increment would be receiving just under $41,000 a year, including their service allowance. ADF data shows that 80 per cent of sergeants have between 10 and 20 years service. They are thus the very people who have to periodically consider whether to sign up for a further five years service. Under the government's changes, a sergeant with 15 years service signing up for another five years will be hit by the provisions of the superannuation tax for that year once their base salary, service allowances and retention benefit were taken into account. This is clearly an example of penny‐pinching at its worst.

Similarly, a warrant officer earning between $43,000 and $50,000 a year, depending on the exact level and increment, would clearly be hit by the full 15 per cent superannuation tax in the year they receive their retention bonus.

Fourthly, the government's position flies completely in the face of the rhetoric of the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel (Mrs Bishop). On 19 September 1996, in response to a dorothy dixer from a coalition backbencher during question time, the minister was heavy in that rhetoric. She said:
I generally want to say that I have found that . . . the former government presided over a decline in morale.

We do not regard the Defence Force as public servants in uniform. We regard them as a very special force of people who give service to this nation and will always be recognised as such by this government.
Specifically, on the question of the retention of pilots, she said:

. . . we are looking at a number of measures to increase the retention rate of pilots. We have in the budget an allocation of $17 million for retention schemes, and that includes a bonus payment scheme, but we are also looking at a range of incentives which are attractive to ensure that pilots will remain within the RAAF and not be lost at the rate that was established under the previous government.

I would be happy to hear the minister explain how the imposition of an additional 15 per cent superannuation tax will do anything to improve the retention rate of pilots and how it is part of giving proper recognition to `the very special force of people who give service to this nation'.

The minister has a habit of engaging in grand rhetorical gestures but of failing to deliver, telling us about all she is going to do for defence personnel but not even being able to speak on this legislation, which brings ADF retention bonuses and benefits into the Treasurer's 15 per cent superannuation tax, creating an absolute debacle on military medals and failing to develop a coherent defence industry policy.

Presumably, these are examples of Minister Bishop's good work that she had in mind when she told the magazine Australian Defence Report that `the Prime Minister, Mr John Howard, was keen to see her continue in her current portfolio to build on the good work that has already been undertaken'. Indeed, the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston, was struck by Mrs Bishop's good work. He was so struck that he told the Senate on Monday that she was `an example of someone in whom there were unrealistic expectations' and unflatteringly linked her with other failed coalition messiahs such as Joh Bjelke-Petersen, Andrew Hay and Katherine West.

What we have here is a serious attack on the retention possibilities of the armed forces in this country. It does fly in the face of that rhetoric that we have heard from the minister so often about how she knows the special requirements and the special needs of the armed forces of this country. Fundamentally, this undermines the efforts of the previous government to retain people who are needed by the armed forces in this country. It is quite disturbing that obviously she has had very little impact with regard to the superannuation debate in the coalition. This is why, unfortunately, it went through to the keeper as far as coalition meetings are concerned and why it will fundamentally mean a very big impost on the armed forces of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis, Arch, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It would appear as though the amendments which I have moved on behalf of the opposition are not going to be supported by the government, even though they deal with the clearest example of retention bonus benefits to defence personnel being unfairly and harshly dealt with under this new superannuation legislation. Given that it would appear as though the most dramatic example of the anomaly that requires rectification is going to be overlooked, I should place on the record a couple of other areas in which allowances are going to be caught by this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, the retention bonus is the most significant and it is the clearest example where people in the three services, particularly in the Air Force, are being asked to stay on by the government. But there are a number of service allowances where payment is made to people in the services because of the additional hardship that they suffer by virtue of the role that they are in. Some of those allowances can be quite significant because the hardship they endure and the requirements placed upon them are dramatically different to that of other personnel in the services. The two clearest examples of that are the submariners and the people in the Special Air Service Regiment.

The simple fact is that submariners quite properly receive an additional increment to take account of the fact that life in a submarine is extremely difficult. It is a hardship to be away from home as long as they are required to. All service on ships, surface ships included, is paid for with an additional increment.

Submariners receive an additional payment on top of the surface fleet because life in a submarine takes special qualities. It is a particular hardship and not everybody can endure it. BREAK.PARA: People in the Special Air Services Regiment, who are highly respected in this parliament by members on all sides and throughout the community, receive additional payment because, unlike others in uniform, they are required to maintain absolute peak capability virtually around the clock. I had the privilege of visiting the SASR a week or two ago and talking to the people there and watching them in some of their training. I have had that privilege on a couple of occasions now. There is no doubt that those people in the SASR are required to maintain a very demanding training schedule, with the physical and mental stress associated with that and with the requirement to shift to other locations literally at a moment's notice for the purposes of their exercise. They are required to maintain that sort of skill, which is not placed upon anyone else in the defence forces. As a result, they quite properly get an additional payment in recognition of that.

Members of the SASR have just had a quite substantial increase in their allowance. I have no doubt that the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel (Mrs Bishop) would want to claim some credit for the increase in the allowance of SASR members. I am not so sure that the minister for defence personnel would want to go out to the SASR and tell those people that, having got that increment, some of them are now going to find themselves losing in their superannuation benefit, not getting more money by virtue of the allowance. As the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson) pointed out, as with the retention bonus, these service allowances do not contribute to enhancing their superannuation payouts. It is not like their fundamental salary, a percentage of which goes into superannuation; it is on top of that. It is excluded from their superannuation contributions.

So they get no gain whatsoever in their superannuation benefit by virtue of those additional allowances. But this government, through this legislation, intends to tax them and actually reduce their superannuation because they happen to be serving in the SASR or because they happen to be submariners. It is a disgraceful situation and it is counterproductive. The simple logic of personnel management should tell the government that you cannot expect to fill the ranks of those critical positions if, on the one hand, you offer them more money each week and then, on the other hand, you surreptitiously take it away from them out of their superannuation when they leave the services. It is a counterproductive, foolish course of action to follow. (Extension of time granted) It is a very foolish arrangement for the government to try to retain those skills—as they do with a retention bonus—and to say to people, `We need you as submariners.' We actually have a shortage of submariners, so we set about spending lots of money to recruit them, giving them this additional bonus on a weekly basis, and then decide that we are going to reduce their superannuation benefits.

Before dinner I did say that I would appreciate a response from the government to my plea that, given their apparent unwillingness to support the motion, they at least give an undertaking to this House that they will, in future, ensure that those people in receipt of retention bonuses are given advice—if they take the retention bonus and do what the government wants them to and sign on for another five years service or stay on as a pilot in the air force or as an air traffic controller—about the implications for their superannuation. I now add to that a request that the government give a clear undertaking in this House tonight that those people in receipt of service allowances also be given advice that that service allowance will, in fact, be included in the calculation of their income for the purposes of levying a superannuation surcharge tax.

If you will not exempt them as the opposition has sought to do in this amendment, at least be honest with them. Do not go behind their backs because, if there is any group of people in the Australian community whom the government has an absolute responsibility to be honest with, it is the service men and women who are willing to put their lives between harm and you and me and everyone else in this community.

It is worth noting that the coalition's defence policy before the last election actually referred to the retention bonuses and said that they would maintain the current arrangements on retention bonuses for ADF personnel. I suppose that is half the truth. I suppose they have kept half the bargain. `Yes, we'll maintain the retention bonus,' say the government. `It's just a bit unfortunate that, for many of you, it will mean that your superannuation payment at the end of your career will be reduced because we're now going to impose a 15 per cent surcharge on you.' And for many that would not have applied, except for the government's insistence that these service payments and retention bonuses count towards income as part of that formula.

I again urge the government to reconsider their position. They had an opportunity when the bill first went through the parliament to amend the legislation to address this anomaly. Because they made so many mistakes with the legislation originally, they now have a second opportunity to amend that legislation. We are giving you that opportunity here in this debate, and I think there will be a lot of service men and women throughout the country who will look eagerly at the government's response.

Words are glib. The assurances and statements of the minister for defence personnel are particularly glib. What you have tonight is an opportunity to put some substance to that and the government can decide in their vote very shortly whether they wish to punish the defence personnel, particularly those in special positions in which we require special skills, or whether they will be honourable with them and exempt them from this tax or at least be honest with them and tell them individually, `This is the impact upon you if you decide to stay on in your important role with us.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Four more Federal MPs have repaid travel allowances as a result of the audit of travel claims.
The fourth paragraph of the article states:
MPs who made recent repayments were:
Queensland Liberal Kathy Sullivan—$145 for one night in Canberra in March 1997.

I say `perhaps', because I do not actually know why this article contains its assertions about me—at no time has Ms Cumming contacted me on any matter relating to the contents of her article. Not only are her conclusions wrong, the article states as fact a series of events that simply have not happened.

The events which did lead to that debit entry are as follows. In late April I received a cheque for my March 1997 travel to Canberra for parliamentary sittings. I immediately realised that I had been paid for one night more than my entitlement. I then contacted the House of Representatives officer who handles these claims, discussed the overpayment with her and sought her advice as to how I should rectify the error.

After the relevant records had been checked, she told me that I should bank the cheque I had received and that when next I submitted a travelling allowance claim, I should note on it that I had been overpaid for a night in March and request that the appro priate adjustment be made. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the fact that I do not have the full 20 minutes, although it has generously been given to me. I am going to conclude my remarks very briefly, in deference to my many colleagues who wish to speak on the Native Title Amendment Bill . I understand the government has indicated I think an unfortunate desire to curtail the total amount of debate on this.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make a couple of points this evening that I did not have time to make last night. In the earlier part of my address I said that I thought the attitudes revealed in this legislative package were very unfortunate and reflected the failure of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to concede—let alone understand—the importance of land and culture to Aboriginal people.

I also outlined the key provisions of the bill and indicated that I had a sense of deja vu after what had occurred in my own state when Premier Court attempted to extinguish native title. I am reminded of words of Mr Chaney—who has had a lot to do with the operation of the native title legislation—in commenting upon this legislation. Mr Chaney, a former senator and a former Liberal, is someone who has an unstinting commitment to the cause of human rights. He said recently:

I can touch only lightly on land issues, because of my present engagement, as a statutory officer, as a member of the National Native Title Tribunal. But all I want to say about double standards in this area is that the entirely appropriate concern for the property rights of miners, the entirely appropriate concern for the property rights of pastoralists, the entirely appropriate concern for the rights of all citizens to enjoy public reserved lands ought to be matched by a similarly appropriate concern for the proper protection of Aboriginal property rights. Few Aboriginal people see a consistent standard here.

Few people on our side of the House see a consistent standard here. The solutions we have offered are contained in this amendment and need to be repeated and underlined. We insist that native title rights are fundamental legal property rights and are entitled to the same respect and protection as other rights of non‐indigenous Australians. We also insist that it is in the national interest that this legislation balances and reconciles the differences and interests and the reasonable expectations of indigenous Australians and of other major stakeholders. One set is not superior to the other. We also insist that it is in the national interest and in the interests of indigenous Australians that there be maximum possible predictability and certainty, something that is lacking in this act. We also insist on the need to guarantee the constitutional validity of this legislation. Again that is something which is conspicuously lacking.

I know I have other colleagues who wish to speak, so all I want to do this evening is note that there are solutions available to this government which it is refusing to hear or allow to be heard. The Australian Law Reform Commission has put forward several recommendations which are being assiduously ignored by the government.

In amending the legislation in line with the various principles that the opposition has insisted on, what the government needs to do, first of all, is to ensure that we reconcile the reasonable interests of all stakeholders—and I emphasise `all'—without diluting Aboriginal rights and without provoking legal challenges and dispute, a course on which the government has entered at the moment. Secondly, along with a great many other Australians interested in this issue, I urge the government, as we do on this side of the House, in a spirit of decency and of leadership to embrace the spirit of the Mabo and Wik decisions and to realise that native title exists and that co‐existence of Aboriginal and pastoral interests is not only possible but also desirable and that reconciliation will not proceed without recognising the rightful title to land of indigenous Australians. Nothing less will do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Before getting down to my own thoughts on this legislation, the speech of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) in this second reading debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997, given earlier in the debate, needs to be answered, if only because so many of her views appear to have a superficial appeal and have been given undeserved merit. I believe that she distorts and misleads, misinterprets and divides, at every turn in her speech. There are few facts there and, therefore, rebuttal is difficult, because much of the speech relies on its negative tone and misplaced anger at what she sees as discrimination against the majority.

SPEECH.PARA: Her speech began with a series of false premises upon which she built an illogical argument, concluding in a flourish of nationalism. I want to look at some of those premises because I think they are instructive. In her very first sentence, the member for Oxley said that Australia had a choice between being `one people belonging to one nation or many peoples belonging to many nations'.

I would remind the member for Oxley that, except in the fantasies of Nazi dictators and some of their latter‐day admirers, a nation is not constituted of pure racial groups but of citizens living within a defined geographical area. In all countries on earth, many different ethnic and racial groups make up each state, and they are governed most successfully by democratic institutions that not only recognise majority rule but also minority rights.

Almost all conflicts in the world today are internal disputes resulting from the oppression by the majority of minority rights, especially rights of cultural expression or economic advancement. Majorities, of their nature, have power. It is minorities who are always in danger of suffering disadvantage and discrimination. It is too great a discrepancy in society that divides a nation, not the according of rights to minorities.

The member for Oxley goes on to say that for many years Australia has been divided by multiculturalism. I think this is simple nonsense. By any standards, Australia has been one of the most cohesive, peaceful and harmonious nations on earth. Multiculturalism has enriched the state. Other nations have allowed demagogues to exploit differences and create violent division, usually for political advantage. Australia has had a bipartisan policy that has successfully blended more than a hundred different ethnic peoples into this country. To say otherwise is to extrapolate from isolated, negative incidents a conclusion at odds with the truth.

The member for Oxley went on to say that there is a need for the High Court to be put back into `its rightful place of interpreting the law, not creating the law'. This is a naive understanding of the role of the courts in a common law system. The courts are in place to answer questions and settle disputes and they do so, in a common law system, on the basis of both statute and, in the absence of statute, precedent. The application of traditional common law principles which were applied in the Mabo and Wik cases is entirely the business of the courts. To clarify and extend the community's understanding of a legal conundrum, within the confines of precedent, is the task of the courts, and they do it every day. In so far as such clarification changes the nature of the law, courts have always been law‐makers. They are one of the branches of power, separated from the legislature and necessarily independent but in a sense working in tandem with the legislature.

The member for Oxley also said that international forces—in other words, the United Nations—are driving the Aboriginal industry to create a separate nation. She implies an international conspiracy, whereas in fact the negotiation for the Draft Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples has been conducted over a long period of time in public forums and has been widely debated. The statement that either in Canada or in Australia a separate nation is being created through native title is simply not true. Native title, whether in Australia or in Canada, gives remarkably little and certainly not separate statehood.

We need to note that native title is a form of title within the nation state, as is freehold or leasehold title. And yet native title is a very different form of title from the usual understanding of property ownership inherent in freehold or even leasehold. It must coexist with leasehold and, where there is a conflict, the rights of the leaseholder prevail. Native title holders are in no sense the sole property owners of the land over which they have been granted title. They must share it with the Crown or with the leaseholder, having only traditional rights and limited negotiation rights over what happens on that land.

Because she chooses to overstate the gains to Aboriginal people offered by the common law recognition of native title, there has been little generosity of spirit or honesty on the part of the member for Oxley on this issue. I would like to quote a former Liberal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Fred Chaney, on what he saw as the double standard in Australia in relation to property rights. This has been quoted before but I think it bears repeating. He said:

The entirely appropriate concern for the property rights of miners, the entirely appropriate concern for the property rights of pastoralists, the entirely appropriate concern for the rights of all citizens to enjoy publicly reserved land ought to be matched by a similarly appropriate concern for the proper protection of Aboriginal property rights.

I also want to comment on the point made by the member for Oxley in her speech on the plot to create a separate Aboriginal state. Anyone who has followed the development of the concept of self‐determination from the immediate post‐colonial days to today would know that the concept has changed. Today it refers to self‐determination for indigenous or minority peoples within the life of the state.

In the Draft Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, self‐determination is defined as the full political participation of indigenous peoples in decision making affecting them, with the provision that it does not imply secession or threaten the territorial integrity of states. Ms Lois O'Donoghue, a former chair of ATSIC, told the 11th session of the Working Group on Indigenous Populations:
Self determination . . . did not imply a suggestion of separatism or secession . . . it is about the right to choose, to have control over one's destiny.
The view of the Canadian observer at the working group in 1993 was that:
. . . indigenous people's right to self‐determination was on the same basis as that of other people, being granted only within the framework of existing nation states.
The Australian government suggested that the draft contain an express limitation on the right so that it could not be detrimental to the territorial integrity of states.

The member for Oxley, when speaking to the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , this bill that we are debating tonight, referred to the Canadian agreement, due to come into effect on 1 April 1999, to split the existing north‐west territories in two and create out of the eastern half a new political subdivision, Nunavut. This agreement, along with a cash settlement of over $Can1 billion over a number of years, was reached only after 16 years of negotiation. It will give the Inuit people direct title to 136,000 square miles and, consequently, self‐determination. This is a positive initiative, enabling the Inuit people—racked by social problems, poverty and low levels of formal education—to take full responsibility for an evolving process of self‐management. Repeated polls have revealed that a majority of English speaking Canadians, around two‐thirds, support the concept of self‐government for indigenous people.

Unfortunately, the member for Oxley, with her usual disregard for factual accuracy and reasoned debate, gratuitously infers that a Nunavut‐like agreement is imminent for Australia—an agreement that took 16 years to negotiate. She goes on to say that Aboriginal disadvantage can be equated with the disadvantage of other mainstream Australians. For all of the problems which many Australians encounter—and many are serious—Aborigines as a group still suffer inordinately greater disadvantage: unemployment of over four times the national average; half to one‐sixth the number participating in higher education; poor health, with a life expectancy 15 to 18 years less than the general population and infant mortality three to five times the national rate, in addition to indigenous people having very high rates of chronic disability, diabetes and eye disease; and substandard housing, water and sewerage, especially for many remote communities. Perhaps as a consequence of all this, incarceration rates for Aborigines is 27 times the non‐Aboriginal rate.

BREAK.PARA: Aboriginal people do not get higher unemployment benefits than other Australians. Unemployed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are entitled to jobsearch and newstart allowances at the same rate as other Australians. Many choose to work for the community development employment program, CDEP, in around 250 communities across the country. The pay is equivalent to or less than unemployment benefits. People on CDEP are treated as wage earners and are thus ineligible for other benefits received by those on income support, such as rent assistance and health concessions. Over 27,000 indigenous people participate in the scheme. Aboriginal people do not receive higher social security benefits than other Australians. In the areas of education and housing, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have access to special benefits in recognition of the fact that they are the most economically and socially disadvantaged group in Australia today.

A variety of programs in universities recognise that many people throughout Australia may be disadvantaged in their educational attainment. There are special admission programs for applicants who have suffered long‐term educational disadvantage due to poverty, disability or severe medical conditions. Special entry programs for indigenous Australians recognise that they are severely disadvantaged in the area of education. It is estimated that only 33 per cent of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students finish secondary school compared to the national rate of more than 77 per cent. Only 17 per cent of indigenous people aged 18 to 20 participate in education compared to 45 per cent of non‐indigenous Australians. Aboriginal people living in remote communities generally have little or no access to secondary and tertiary education facilities—and so I could go on.

It is not only the member for Oxley, in her speech, who claims that ATSIC is corrupt and inefficient; I have heard others say it as well. To that claim I reply: if that is the case then it should be audited like all other institutions. It is then up to governments to deal with the inefficiencies or the corruption. However, the member for Oxley has again exaggerated. Fred Chaney says:

ATSIC is condemned to failure because it is asked to do too much . . . The truth is that ATSIC is in many areas required to perform most if not all of the functions of State and Local Government but it is not funded adequately to do so. More than one‐third of the ATSIC budget is spent on work for the dole and a substantial part of the remainder goes in providing services which would normally be provided by State and Local governments. ATSIC has little money and less energy left to tackle the more vital and particularly Aboriginal issues of building community and individual morale, skill and competence.

In the 1996‐97 budget, ATSIC funding was $959.92 million. Most of that budget is spent on the CDEP scheme, Aboriginal housing and essential infrastructure programs—services provided to the rest of the community by state and local government.

ATSIC is subject to the usual processes of public accountability applicable to all public sector spending. In October 1996 the special auditor appointed to review accountability within ATSIC funded organisations found that, of the 1,122 organisations reviewed, 95 per cent were cleared for funding. The special auditor issued 60 `not fit and proper' determinations—five per cent of the organisations reviewed. Of these, most related to late lodgment of financial and management information, late lodgment of acquittal information and failure to lodge project performance records. The problems were linked to the small size of organisations and the need for management training—not corruption.

Finally, when dealing with matters raised by the member for Oxley, there is the perverse logic in the view that the native title decisions of the High Court or the Native Title Act should have offended against the Racial Discrimination Act. I fail to understand how the most grossly disadvantaged group in our community—people who have been dispersed, dispossessed and murdered, and whose struggle to reach even the most basic and acceptable standards continues daily—can have discriminated against the majority by being given limited and often largely symbolic rights over land they formerly held in total.

Mr Deputy Speaker, let me turn to other matters concerning this bill. On a personal level, I find myself in a difficult position. For the past six years I have been a member of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, and I am supportive of the process—that is, of seeking to negotiate a solution that is acceptable to all sides of the argument.

As a former shadow minister, I visited many communities, and I am very much aware of the different way in which Aboriginal people view land. An Aboriginal person's country forms the basis of their creation stories, religion and culture. Land is the core for relationships between people, past and future generations; an inherent link between kinship, spirituality and custody, as opposed to the European concept of ownership which brings economic power.

One of my concerns is that, in seeking a solution to the native title issue, we are not placing enough emphasis on the importance of land to its Aboriginal custodians. We have an issue of `guardianship versus ownership', a legal versus moral argument; and an issue that, unless it is resolved with the agreement of all involved parties—indigenous custodians, pastoralists, miners, all levels of government—will cost our country billions of dollars in litigation and compensation.

The Native Title Amendment Bill 1997, as it stands, does not, in my view, provide certainty to all stakeholders. States and territories can determine native title activities—and, unfortunately, historically their record is poor in this regard.

Finally, Mr Deputy Speaker, let me state, in essence, my concerns about this legislation. Apart from the foreseeable difficulties of passing it through the Senate and the enormous cost to the community through compensation claims and litigation costs, I think the perceived outcomes of the Wik decision have been overstated. For many generations on many leases, Aboriginal people have co-existed with pastoralists and have had rights to move over the land. The Wik decision determined that the granting of a pastoral lease did not necessarily extinguish native title; that native title could coexist with the rights of the leaseholder; and that the rights of pastoralists prevail over any rights of the native titleholders. The number of pastoral leaseholders who have to coexist with native title holders is relatively small; that is, small enough to successfully negotiate any conflict situations if they arise—but, it would seem to me, not large enough to justify extinguishment, and all that that entails, of native title on pastoral leasehold land on a large scale basis.

I do have my doubts about this bill. I do have concerns about the unedifying prospect of future litigation—thereby negating any claims of certainty. And I do have serious concerns about the impact of this legislation on the reconciliation process. Some may say, `Well, in that case why are you going to support the bill?' I must say that I will not vote against the legislation because it seems to me that to do so would be seen as a rather fruitless exercise. But I do believe that, as an expression of my deep concern, it is important that I state my position on the public record.

As I say, if I were to vote against this legislation, I think the media would use that for other political purposes. But my conscience requires that I place on record my deep reservations about this particular piece of legislation: I believe that it disadvantages further those already disadvantaged, and that it will not provide the results sought so vehemently by the wider community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me begin by complimenting the member for Aston (Mr Nugent) for the courageous speech he has made here tonight and the fact that he has recognised—as I am sure other members in his party would have recognised—that the current legislation, the Native Title Amendment Bill, will not achieve the results which the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has maintained it will achieve; it will create more problems for Australia both within the nation and internationally. Mr Deputy Speaker, in support of that fact, you only had to see tonight's news reports of some British and European members of parliament talking already of the possibility of boycotting the 2000 Olympics because of the incredible reputation we as a nation are gaining in relation to these matters.

BREAK.PARA: Let me make it clear: we in the Labor Party do not agree with such a boycott. But those who think that we can, as a nation, simply put our head in the sand and make determinations that are contrary to justice for our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are mistaken. They know, in fact, that this will rebound on us as a nation. We ought to be very conscious of that.

However, I am very happy to be participating in this debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997. It is a debate which I think will be of historic importance to our nation. Many of the detailed issues have been discussed by my colleagues in the Labor Party. I believe that the arguments against the Prime Minister's 10‐point plan, especially as that plan is embedded in this legislation, are overwhelming. It is said that the government has failed to heed not only the views of the indigenous people and of the opposition parties, but also the thought out contribution of its own Australian Law Reform Commission.

We have already heard in this chamber about the shenanigans which have occurred in trying to hide from the public the views of the Australian Law Reform Commission. Those views are very important: they emphasise not only the injustices in this matter but also the fact that what will happen is that, rather than this legislation resolving issues, we will have a greater number of legal issues, a greater number of constitutional issues and a greater number of issues before the High Court than we had before. I do not know why the Prime Minister has not listened to the government's own Australian Law Reform Commission. But, never mind, that is the way in which things are moving with this government.

Many of the reasons put forward by the Prime Minister in supporting, in effect, a form of extinguishment of native title are bogus. What we have here is not an intellectually rigorous attempt to come to grips with the issues, but rather an exercise intended to assuage the unjustified concerns created in the minds of pastoralists and other non-indigenous Australians, and to please these people. The Prime Minister's approach talks about `swinging the pendulum back' towards a more balanced view—I saw him on television talking about `swinging the pendulum back'—as if the native title legislation of 1993 and the Wik decision have been too generous or too fair to the Aboriginal people.

Where is the Prime Minister coming from? What sort of sense of history does he have, if he thinks that the native title legislation and the Wik decision are too fair or too generous? Obviously, he does not understand what has happened historically in relation to the extraordinary fate of the Aboriginal people. This extraordinary statement which has been made by the Prime Minister has unfortunately been promulgated enthusiastically in the media, thereby creating the impression that the indigenous people of this country are now being excessively compensated—excessively compensated—for past sufferings. What an absurdity!

This insidious propaganda line has even led to a situation where people living in suburban blocks in the cities feel threatened by native title. That is how far the nonsense has extended, and nothing could be further from the truth. The idea of coexistence between the rights of pastoralists and the rights under native title is certainly an idea that can work and must be made to work if we are to have justice in this society. The fundamental reason why this is so has to do with the dramatic role which the land plays in the very structure of Aboriginal culture.

As I have said before in this parliament, the fundamental philosophy of the Aboriginal people is a world view and a metaphysical system in which the spiritual elements of life are intertwined with the physical elements of life through the medium of the land. It was very interesting to hear the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) in his contribution yesterday say that land was unimportant to Aborigines. Where is he coming from? There is not a single Aboriginal culture that does not hold the land as sacred and dramatically important. He does not know what he is saying. He was completely wrong. The whole contribution was a disgrace.

Land is fundamentally important to the very existence of Aboriginal people and the way they conceive themselves in the world. This has been understood for many years. In the book In the World of the First Australians, Kathryn and Ronald Berndt had this to say:

In comparison with many others, and certainly in comparison with Europeans, the Aborigines were a deeply religious people. Religious feeling was manifested through ritual observance and through mythic expression—and, essentially, taken for granted. And an intrinsic part of it was a deep emotional attachment to the land, their own land. The whole countryside was full of signs and clues that were directly and indirectly relevant to their lives. It was made familiar and intimate to them through mythic beings who were believed to be manifested at specific sites, always present and approachable through the medium of ritual. There were eternal or enduring elements, underlining continuity sustained through religious practice. At one conceptual level, everything was brought together into one expanded sociocultural environment. The deities were manifested predominantly through man, and other living things and other features were selected as intermediaries or symbolic representations: all drew on the same life force.

This point about land is reinforced by many Aboriginal persons who have expressed themselves quite emotionally on this matter. For example, an Aboriginal Uniting Church minister is quoted in the book A Certain Heritage as saying:

The land my mother. Like a human mother, the land gives us protection, enjoyment, and provides for our needs—economic, social and religious. We have a human relationship with the land: mother‐daughter, son. When the land is taken from us or destroyed, we feel hurt because we belong to the land and we are part of it.
Mr Yunupingu, a former member of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and a prominent Aboriginal leader, says:
The land is my backbone . . . I only stand straight, happy, proud and not ashamed about my colour because I still have land. I can paint, dance, create and sing as my ancestors did before me.

I think of land as the history of my nation. It tells me of how we came into being and by what system we must live. My great ancestors who lived in the times of history, planned everything that we practise now. The law of history says that we must not take land, fight over land, steal land, give land and so on. My land is mine only because I came in spirit from that land, and so did my ancestors of the same land . . . My land, is my foundation.
Our responsibility as a nation for the destruction of so much of Aboriginal culture over the last 200 years is clear and undeniable.

In destroying much of the culture of Aborigines through our treatment of them, we totally undermined the basis of their identity as a people. The majority of our indigenous peoples became lost souls in this process, having lost touch with their traditional roots and the traditional links with those lands that provided them with their identity. Unfortunately, we cannot restore all this. We cannot bring back the totality of the richness of the cultures that we have destroyed, but we have an overwhelming moral imperative to do a lot more. The Mabo decision and the Native Title Act provide us with the opportunity to take concrete steps to redress these historical wrongs. That is what we did in bringing down that legislation.

The Wik decision threw out a further challenge to us: to be a generous society, to show compassion, to show the world that we are prepared to do something to remedy the wrongs we have done to the indigenous people of this country. Instead, how have we responded as a society? Our media, to their utter disgrace, have promulgated sensational lies and created totally unfounded fears in the minds of the population. They have tried to create the impression that the indigenous people of this country are now being excessively compensated for past sufferings.

This insidious propaganda line, promulgated in particular by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) and the member for Kalgoorlie and others but unfortunately supported indirectly through this bill, has even led to a situation where people living in suburban blocks in the cities feel threatened by native title. Many of the points put forward in the Prime Minister's 10‐point Wik plan, as I mentioned, are bogus.

Let me say something about this bogus plan. The Prime Minister's approach suggests that there cannot be coexistence between the rights of pastoralists and the rights of indigenous people under native title. As I have mentioned, this is an idea that can work. The High Court, when it delivered its judgment on 23 December 1996, said that the grant of a pastoral lease does not necessarily extinguish all native title rights. How are you going to get around that? You can try whatever you like about extinguishment, but you will not get around that.

The High Court said that pastoral leases do not give exclusive possession to the pastoralists. It said that native title rights continue at the same time that the land is subject to a pastoral lease. Whatever you do with this 10‐point plan, you will not get around the fundamental point of the High Court's pronouncements. What you will do by this extinguishment process is simply reopen a whole process at the High Court. Even if we pass this legislation unamended, we will have to go back to the High Court, because it will be challenged for its constitutionality and in terms of the Wik determination.

Rather, we could have a process of conciliation, negotiation and discussion between ourselves and the indigenous people in which we work out a coexistence arrangement for both the rights of pastoralists and the rights of indigenous people under native title. The High Court itself explained that a native title holder could not exclude the holder of a pastoral lease from the area of that pastoral lease or restrict pastoralists from using the lease area for pastoral purposes.

For example, a native title holder would not be able to do anything which interfered with the ability of the pastoralists' livestock to take advantage of the pasture and the water resources of the land; which interfered with the pastoralists' privacy on the homestead; and which interfered with the pastoralists' right to build fences, gates, windmills and other improvements on the land. This was in the determination.

Under these circumstances there is no reason why we should seek to extinguish any rights under native title in order to protect pastoralists. Their interests can be protected in a fair system such as that which the indigenous working group have suggested to the parliament. They have produced a statement titled `Coexistence—Negotiation and Certainty: Indigenous Position in Response to the Wik Decision and the Government's Proposed Amendments to the Native Title Act, 1993'.

They have put forward a number of key principles—for example, the principles of non-discrimination as set out in the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 which they say are binding on Australia under CERD and which under international law must be fully respected. It is absolutely correct. If we have a situation in which this act goes through and its challenge is contrary to the Racial Discrimination Act, and indeed to the High Court's own determination on Wik, we will be ridiculed internationally because we have produced the Racial Discrimination Act and we have signed international agreements relating to these matters, yet we are going to produce legislation that is challengeable on this basis.

We really are in a very difficult position which we need not be in had the government been prepared to discuss the matter seriously. Instead, the Prime Minister went through a nonsensical process, and the Aboriginal leaders simply could not believe the treatment they received from him. He simply produced his own dogmatic plan and was not prepared to really get into serious discussions and negotiations with our indigenous people to achieve a possible compromise.

The indigenous working group's statement is extremely sensible. It does not say, `All of the native title claims of the indigenous people have to be met.' It says, `Let's have a look at them. Let's have a sensible process. Let's have a process of discussion and negotiation in which those who are making native title claims and the pastoralists and the miners can come together and work out agreements through a negotiated process.' Instead, the Prime Minister has sought to get rid of this whole process and substitute it with his Wik plan. Let us face it: even the Leader of the National Party (Mr Fischer) has described it as bucketfuls of extinguishment. What is that supposed to mean? It means extinguishment of native title rights.

We then are told by others that it is not really going to extinguish anything. The reality is that the indigenous people of this nation have a lot to fear from this legislation because it will extinguish so much. It has swung the pendulum back all right: it has swung the pendulum back completely in the opposite direction—against the Aboriginal people. The Prime Minister ought to be ashamed as leader of this country for putting forward these proposals and achieving this kind of result.
Mr Deputy Speaker, I have been told to wind up by the Opposition Whip. I would like to conclude with this comment from the former Prime Minister, Paul Keating, who said:

Isn't it reasonable to say that if we can build a prosperous and remarkably harmonious multicultural society in Australia, surely we can find just solutions to the problems which beset the first Australians—the people to whom the most injustice has been done. The starting point might be to recognise that the problem starts with us non‐Aboriginal Australians. It begins, I think, with that act of recognition. Recognition that it was we who did the dispossessing. We took the traditional lands and smashed the traditional way of life. We brought the diseases. The alcohol. We committed the murders. We took the children from their mothers. We practised discrimination and exclusion.
It was our ignorance and our prejudice. And our failure to imagine these things being done to us.
We must give justice to the Aboriginal people. We must pass the amendments that the Labor Party is putting forward to this 10‐point plan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Causley, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with some interest to the contributions to this debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill and have to say that I feel rather saddened by a lot of it. In a lot of instances, the information that has been put forward is erroneous and, in some cases, probably deliberately mischievous. That is very sad because this is an issue that is very important to this country. It is an issue that needs to be resolved and resolved quickly if we are going to have the reconciliation that a lot of us and a lot of members in this House have spoken about.

SPEECH.PARA: I am a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund. We have heard a number of submissions from a number of different groups on this particular subject. The problem that raises its head is the fact that while the High Court has made two decisions—one in Mabo and one in Wik—there are still a lot of questions that have not been answered.

BREAK.PARA: One of the fundamental questions—and I was interested to hear the member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) and the member for Aston (Mr Nugent) talk about this—is the access to land and hunting, gathering and ceremonial rights. There seems to be a myth abroad that that is what the High Court decided. The High Court did not decide that. In fact, it said in Wik that just because a grazing lease had been granted over that land—and I might say that both of those leases are not current leases; one I do not think was taken up and the other was abandoned—it did not necessarily extinguish native title. It did not say what native title was and it did not say on what lands it might apply. That is the fundamental problem that we have in this whole debate. I have listened to a lot of evidence before the native title committee that has assumed a lot of things. Unfortunately, there is misinformation being peddled—I suspect by some members of the opposition—about this whole area.

The facts are that this parliament has a responsibility. There has been criticism of the High Court making law, which is not its responsibility. But if this parliament abdicates its responsibility then it will be left to the High Court to make law. We do have a responsibility here to try to clarify and interpret the decisions of the High Court. There is no doubt that there is an industry out there that has been developed of professional people—lawyers, anthropologists and even planners—who I do not think have a real interest in solving this particular problem but are certainly trying to extend the boundaries of the High Court decision.

In fact, we have even heard evidence from some of the Aboriginal leaders that they do not believe the High Court is talking about hunting, gathering and ceremonial rights on land where it has not been extinguished. They believe something greater. Only last week in Cairns, Mr Pearson, when questioned, said that he believed native title was prime title, that it took primacy over crown. That is quite different to some of the arguments that have been put forward in this parliament. You can understand some of the concerns out there in the community when these types of suggestions are put forward.

We have had evidence on two occasions from Aboriginal leaders who have said they believed native title meant that they owned the land, they owned the minerals, they owned the water and they owned the air space. That is obviously a belief amongst certain people that is quite contrary to some of the argument that is being put forward by the opposition and others as to what native title is really about.

What the 10-point plan is endeavouring to do is to, in many ways, codify and take what we believe to be the High Court's decision and clarify some of the unanswered questions. When the committee has asked how long it might take the High Court through case law to clarify this particular issue, the answer has been that it will take at least two decades. I put to you that this country cannot wait two decades to decide this particular issue.

Native title is an issue suddenly arising because there is no doubt the first governments of this country believed they were acting in good faith and believed they were abiding by the world law at the time of allocating land. There is no doubt the Aboriginal people were dispossessed. It was sometimes a very brutal dispossession. There is no doubt about that, and I do not think that is new to Australia or any other country. In fact, my forebears come from the south of England. I put it to you that they were probably dispossessed three or four times. So it is nothing new in the history of countries for peoples to have been dispossessed.

I admit that even today the Aboriginal people are a disadvantaged group within our community, and we should be doing everything we can to try to help them. I do believe there is an issue building up in this country whereby people are giving them a hope that will not be achieved. There will be very great disappointment when the High Court does come down or clarify some of these issues.

While the 1993 act was obviously put forward in good faith to try to address the issues at that particular time, there is also a rewriting of history by many people at the present time. If you go back and look at the quotes that came from the then Prime Minister, from Mr Pearson, from Rick Farley, who was representing the National Farmers Federation at the time, and from the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans) when he was in the Senate, there was a clear understanding that there was a bit of horse trading going on in the 1993 act. Groups were got together by the then Prime Minister and others and told, `Look, we have to get some compromise on this particular issue.'

There was a clear understanding at that particular time that, in give and take, the act was going to give extinguishment of native title on pastoral leases. You only have to read the quotes to get that indication very clearly. It is history, of course, that the Wik decision came down and said that it did not necessarily mean that, and we have to accept that. No-one is trying to overrule the court's decision. This bill is not trying to overrule the court's decision; it is accepting what the High Court has said and is trying to clarify it.

Much has been said about the comment of the Leader of the National Party (Mr Anderson) about there being bucket loads of extinguishment. I go through the bill and ask myself, `Where are these bucket loads of extinguishment?' They are not in the bill. In evidence we have before the committee, people cannot substantiate where these extinguishments take place.

There is no doubt there can be a conflict between two titles. What the bill is saying is that if an upgrading does occur on a lease—and usually it is only a portion of a lease on which upgrading occurs—and because of that upgrading there is exclusive possession, then that will naturally override the native title rights and compensation must be paid. That is an area where you have two conflicting titles. But under the constitution, because there is a property right denied, they have to be compensated, and the bill takes note of that.

There is the issue of revival. If we look at the quotes from former Senator Evans in the debate in the Senate in 1993, he made it very clear that in his understanding native title could not revive after title had been granted on a piece of land. If they are about the only two areas that you could talk about, there may be some semblance of the fact that native title has been extinguished.

Most people agree that the 1993 act is not working. In fact, the former government had amendments before this parliament before the election, admitting that the 1993 act needed amendment. If you look at some of the evidence given by Aboriginal people, they say that they believe that the act is not working in many ways. In fact, there are a number of competing claims. Because of the fact that a belief has been built up that this is to do with money and that a native title claim gives some right to money, there are a number of Aboriginal people—brothers and sisters—claiming the same land. That is plainly ludicrous and has to be resolved. Aboriginal people agree with that.

I turn to the issue of access. No-one is trying to deny Aboriginal people access to land for their religious or ceremonial beliefs or rights. In fact, even in Queensland, where there is not a right of access under the present legislation, there have been agreements between pastoralists and Aboriginal people to have access to that land. I believe that those voluntary agreements are the way we should go. This act agrees and puts in place a regime whereby you can have these voluntary agreements whereby people can have access to the land. No-one is trying to deny them that. It is a cruel hoax for the opposition to go out there and say that these people are to be denied. They are not.

There are many areas in this bill that are just trying to amend the previous 1993 act to make it workable. One area is the right to negotiate, which at present occurs twice. For example, in mining instances, at the mining lease stage there is a right to negotiate and then if you go ahead and open up a mine, there is another right to negotiate. I argue that native title rights do not change from the time that you go from a lease to a mine. Yes, there is disturbance. That is the same with any property owner; he has to be compensated for disturbance. No doubt, mining companies have to take note of heritage sites, but that can all be agreed in the one process. There do not have to be two processes. It can be streamlined to ensure that that can all be taken into account in due process. I think that that obviously is a very sensible amendment to try to overcome some of the delays and frustrations.

At the end of the day, if we do not have these developments and if we do not have industry, whether it be grazing or mining, none of us in Australia can enjoy the standard of living that we have today and the benefits that accrue from that. Whether we are of European descent, Asian descent or Aboriginal descent, none of us can enjoy those rights, so it is important that the country itself is allowed to develop and benefit from the gains that certainly come from that industry.

As I said, I am saddened by some of the debate that is taking place on this particular issue. Having grown up in the country and spent a lot of time with Aboriginal people, I know their aspirations. Their aspirations are no different to anyone else's. There are 18 million people in Australia. You cannot go back to the time when Aboriginal people roamed this country. Unfortunately, you cannot turn back the clock. It is one of those things where we have to look to the future. There is no doubt in my mind that the future is not going to be spent squabbling over native title. The High Court has decided that there is a remnant common law right. This parliament is recognising that right. There is no doubt in my mind that we now have to deal with it. It is a difficult and emotional issue.

There are all sorts of furphies floating around. It is very disappointing to see some of them—for instance, the exaggeration over the possible upgrading of leases. That has always been the right under all state government regimes. Lessees have always had the right to apply to upgrade. There is nothing new in this legislation. It has always been there. The exaggeration that people are going to go out there and upgrade and freehold and deny Aboriginal people rights is plainly wrong and mischievous.

We also have the furphy floating around that this in some way will benefit the National Party or members of the coalition who come from the country. To my knowledge, there are only two members of the government who might have some interest in leases, yet the opposition has gone out there and talked about 28, which is plainly a lie. All of this emotion and nastiness that has been put around the place to try to push this particular issue is not gaining any credit at all.

We should look at foreign ownership. It has been very interesting to take evidence from the state governments because there is this myth being peddled that these great areas of Australia are owned by foreign interests. In fact, in New South Wales there is very little. If you go across Australia, somewhere between two and three per cent of the land mass is owned by foreign interests.

The great majority—99 per cent and more—of the lessees in Australia are Australian families. They have a problem at present because of the uncertainty that we have surrounding this particular debate. The problem they have is common to anyone when you have uncertainty, particularly with financial institutions. We received evidence the other day of cases where leases are considered unsaleable because of the uncertainty surrounding this. While they will not come out and say it publicly, banks are saying, `We're not real certain about the title that you hold over this particular land', and they are not giving finance to people to carry on.

This country cannot carry on this way. We have to resolve this. There is no doubt that this parliament, as I said earlier, has a responsibility. We are the law makers, we are the people who can pass laws in this country to ensure certainty. It is not about dispossessing Aboriginal people, it is about certainty. It is about trying to clarify a new law—a new property right—found by the High Court which in fact conflicts with some of the property rights that have been granted in this country. I think that this 10‐point plan goes a long way to resolving many of these issues. Might I say that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has sat down with all interest groups to try to resolve this particular problem—despite what people might say. It is a very thorny problem, as I have said.

Another issue that has gained quite a lot of interest in the hearings that we have had concerns schedule 4. Schedule 4 relates to a number of leases that the crown law officers of the states and the crown law office of the Commonwealth have sat down about to try to narrow the areas that are at odds. These leases are considered, after reading the leases—and the Wik decision made it fairly clear that, if exclusive possession was granted, then that would have an influence on native title—to be exclusive leases.

There is a lot of discontent on both sides about this. On one side we have the advisers and the Aboriginal people saying that some of these leases should not have been included. On the other side we have leases that have been left out, and most states are dissatisfied with the fact that a number of leases have been left out.
