The ones that come to mind quickly are the pastoral leases in western New South Wales. As lands minister in New South Wales, I was always given the advice that those leases were next to freehold. But because the words are not clearly there in the leases, the law officers have said they cannot include them in schedule 4. In the evidence that we have received it is fairly clear that the law officers have been meticulous in going through these leases to see whether in fact they consider the words to say `exclusive possession'.

Again, I think the plan has been very thorough in trying to resolve some of these issues, trying to clarify issues, trying to cut down the delays that we might have in trying to take all this through the High Court. I have been very interested in some of the comments from the opposition because it seems to me that what they are saying is that this parliament should butt out and the High Court should run this country. I do not believe that is the responsibility of the High Court. Certainly, the High Court is there to define law, to give decisions on statute law, but it is not its job to run the country. It is this parliament's job to run the country, it is this parliament's job to try to clarify law, it is this parliament's job to make law. I believe this 10‐point plan is certainly trying to do that in a very fair and a very honourable way. I congratulate the Prime Minister for bringing it forward. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I would like to indicate my congratulations to the member for Aston (Mr Nugent) for a truly remarkable contribution to this debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill. His speech showed tremendous courage and his contribution is one which I will take with me beyond my parliamentary career.

SPEECH.PARA: The contribution of the member for Page (Mr Causley) was, unfortunately, quite disappointing. He indicated that the government's desire is to resolve these matters and to resolve them quickly. All the academic debate indicates that this bill will do nothing of the sort. It will complicate and delay any sensible resolution of matters which should be resolved through a consensus process.

He indicated, quite mischievously, in a scaremongering fashion that the banks—he will not say publicly how he gets his information and I do not know—are not prepared to lend in respect of pastoral leases. He is well aware that the banks are on the record as saying that they have never lent on the basis of the proprietary value of the land itself for pastoral leaseholdings. They have always lent on the basis of capital improvements and stock on that land and they have said that nothing has changed since the Wik decision. That is part of a scaremongering tactic being advanced by those in the conservative ranks.

He said that it is the job of this parliament to run the country, which no doubt is true, but he said it offensively in the context that the High Court should butt out. That is offensive. It is the job of this parliament to run the country, but to run it in accordance with constitutional principles that we have inherited from the Magna Carta and that have been worked through by our constitutional founders consistent with those principles. It is offensive in the extreme to even suggest that the High Court have purported to introduce legislation. They have construed legislation against those fundamental principles which many decent men and women have died face down in the mud for. They are guardians of those fundamental liberties and principles. That comment was offensive in the extreme.

This government's attitude is not only demonstrated in its propaganda of controlling the source of information but also demonstrated most clearly in its approach to the Australian Law Reform Commission, which gave a very learned, thorough and thoughtful analysis of this legislation. Rather than admitting that their advice was on the table as a contribution to the debate, this government has sought to suppress that information. That itself is bad government and is offensive and insulting to the Australian people.

In terms of the legislation itself, the Labor Party has indicated that it would support legislation to provide legal certainty to pastoral leaseholders. It has indicated that it would be prepared to support legislation to refine and clarify aspects of claims under the Native Title Act. But the ALP's position is fundamentally based on a bottom line of ensuring respect for the native title of Aboriginal Australians. Native title is a common law right based on Aboriginal occupation and use of this land for some 30,000 years. What this government effectively seeks to do is reinvent history to determine that 200‐odd years ago it was an unsettled continent. It cannot reverse history. It was in fact a settled continent, settled by an ancient race recognised internationally.

Pastoral leaseholders may well have been disappointed that the High Court confirmed in the Wik case that their leases were something other than proprietary rights. But the facts of the matter are that the leases were the leases as contained in the terms of the leases. They are licences to graze hard‐hoofed animals on vast tracts of land. Usually, indeed, they are arid tracts of land capable of sustaining very few stock; sometimes as few as one animal per 50 acres. In the Wik case itself, the history of the pastoral leases was analysed in terms of their origins from the occupation by squatters and how regulations had to be in place to clarify the position of those squatters, after they started to develop industry on the pastoral leaseholdings, to actually invest in infrastructure and go about the business of developing the land.

So the leasing arrangements are in that context. The leases never had the intention of giving and have never given the leaseholders a proprietary right. Indeed, given the massive tracts of land involved, it would be completely untenable to give so much of Australia to so few individuals. Seeking to literally give such vast tracts of land to so few individuals would remove the ability of all Australians to have an input to what is developed on that land. For instance, Australians generally, through their governments, would lose the ability to ensure that unsustainable land uses such as broad scale land clearing, intense irrigated agriculture, native forest logging and unregulated tourism do not occur. If pastoral leases were simply handed over to so few individuals, Australians would lose that input. In short, the land of Australia is part of the heritage of all Australians, and elevating the status of pastoral leases to private proprietary rights would effectively deny all Australians, not just Aboriginal Australians, their heritage.

In terms of addressing whether this legislation will achieve the result that is sought by the government, one does not need to read the opinion of legal scholars. Quite clearly, it is a detriment to the Aboriginal people, just as much as it would be if anyone was to march into one or other of our houses and deny that we had a proprietary interest in that entitlement. The legislation is fundamentally flawed from a constitutional point of view, and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) has made an excellent contribution to that aspect of the debate, as indeed has the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham), who has just entered the chamber. I think the argument that they advance is unassailable, that quite clearly it will be determined by the High Court of Australia that the race power contained in the constitution can only be used to the overall benefit of the Aboriginal race. It will therefore fail under the race power. Indeed, a Canadian royal commission examined a not dissimilar situation in that country and they determined in that case that the government had a fiduciary obligation to the native inhabitants. That reasoning, I am sure, will be consistent here.

Aside from the race power, the other avenue of potential power is the international affairs power. It is clear from Victoria v. The Commonwealth that the domestic law must be consistent with any international treaty upon which it is based. This legislation impliedly repeals those provisions of the Race Discrimination Act which prevent happening something which the member for Kennedy erroneously advanced as being possible, that is, states cannot, as a result of a High Court decision in a case involving the Western Australian government, upgrade pastoral leases to override native title because by doing so they are discriminating against the Aboriginal race. That cannot occur. But this legislation, in impliedly repealing those provisions of the Race Discrimination Act, inconsistently with international treaty obligations which offend against the principles relating to the construction of the foreign affairs power.
I underline that point with a question by Hal Wootton, a member of the Native Title Tribunal. He said:

What do you do if you want to acquire somebody's property? Do those who want to acquire it get together on their own—someone used the word conspire here—how to take it off them? Or do they go and make an offer, negotiate in other words. If it were anyone except Aboriginals the answer would be obvious to all.

It is a shame the government does not come out quite clearly and say what it is doing, that is, discriminating against the Aboriginal people. It is about compulsory, non‐consensual extinction of clearly identified native title rights. Not only does this bill actually extinguish native title in circumstances of past inconsistent usage; it also permits future Commonwealth, state and territory governments to upgrade pastoral leases so that extinguishment occurs in the future.

The government itself has indicated that blanket extinguishment would give rise to massive compensation payments, so it has tried to do it by delay and subterfuge. Nonetheless, it is still putting in place a regime for that to occur. On the authority of Koara's case, compensation is not simply the monetary value of the property. Quite clearly, that compensation must have regard to the cultural significance and resource significance of the land to the Aboriginal Australians. So this government is casting upon taxpayers generally, by a philosophically driven piece of legislation, the cost of paying a massive compensation bill.

The bill fails to recognise that the international community regards Aboriginal culture as very much part of Australia's culture. The reality is that, after the lessons of Nazism and apartheid, the international community regards racism with complete and utter abhorrence. There is no question that Australia will pay very dearly indeed if it is perceived by the international community as racially discriminatory, particularly against its black indigenous people. It was referred to earlier tonight, for instance, that there have been comments that European countries—not black African countries—are looking very seriously at whether they will participate in the Olympic Games if this legislation goes through. That would be a real tragedy for Australia.

This bill is discriminatory because it seeks to bestow special opportunities and privileges on one group of Australians at the expense of a racial group, namely Aboriginal Australians. Under this bill they can be forced to give up their land against their will, despite the High Court determining that they have native title over the land. I recall a speech by the member for Kennedy which seemed to have the music of the Twilight Zone playing in the background where he suggested that claims of native title were something akin to some sort of communist plot. The reality is that the High Court has recognised the proprietary right of Aboriginal people and it is this government that is doing what authoritarian governments do: simply attempting to take over and negate the proprietary rights which the High Court has determined clearly exist.

Unquestionably this is discriminatory legislation and it is repugnant to the majority of decent, fair-minded Australians. Further, it is complete and utter hypocrisy that on 30 October 1996 this parliament reaffirmed its commitment to the rights of all Australians to enjoy equal rights and to be treated with equal respect regardless of race, colour, creed or origin. How can Australians have faith in this parliament when it seeks to regard its own motions with such disdain as is demonstrated by this bill?

BREAK.PARA: Until we learn to treat the Aboriginal inhabitants of this nation with respect and to afford them the same rights as all other Australians in accordance with fundamental, constitutional and moral principles, then we are diminished as a nation and in the eyes of the world. Worse still, in terms of our own self‐respect we will have not much to be proud of and much to be ashamed of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quick, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I start my speech on the Native Title Amendment Bill, I would like to acknowledge the contribution by my learned colleague the member for Barton (Mr McClelland) and the legal expertise that he brings to this rather sensitive issue. Each of us brings to this debate our own individual perspective. Much has already been said concerning this most controversial bill which is before the House tonight. Emotions are running high, with both sides of this place seemingly concreted into positions on totally opposite sides of the spectrum, and there appears to be little chance of agreement. This saddens me.

SPEECH.PARA: As a member of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund since its inception in 1994 as a result of the Native Title Act, I have wandered across this nation listening to the many divergent opinions put forward by all those who have been involved with the issue of native title—indigenous people throughout the country, pastoralists in the many states and territories, people with mining concerns, local governments, state governments and ordinary citizens.

There are views as to the effectiveness or otherwise of the bill in its original form. There are views as to the initial Howard amendments, the so-called exposure draft. There are views concerning the High Court Wik decision and finally the Howard 10‐point plan and the Native Title Amendment Bill that we are discussing here tonight. In my honest and humble opinion this bill is a watershed in our nation's history. If we do not get this sensitive issue right this time around, then conflict and social dislocation the like of which we see so frequently overseas on our nightly television reports will occur surely here in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: I do not intend to speak for long tonight to canvass the issues raised by all sides in this debate. The joint committee is shortly to present its report on this very bill and I hope to speak to this report at greater length later on this week. But several things are clear to me. This government, in its attempt to clear the uncertainty generated by the initial Native Title Bill, the Brandy case and the Wik judgment, has been unswervingly pursuing the 10‐point plan and these amendments, which in my mind will generate far more uncertainty for all concerned and will generate a bitterness that will linger long in our nation's history.

I listened with an open heart as a member of the joint native title committee to the concerns of the young pastoralist in Broome the other week as he spoke at length of his anguish at not being able to proceed with his plans to develop his pastoral lease. I also listened to the Aboriginal man who took up a piece of paper and said so accurately to our committee, `I don't care how many black words you write on this white piece of paper. This land has always belonged to my people—to my father and his father before him.'

I have listened as a layman to the conflicting legal arguments put by those representing the indigenous people, the various levels of state and local government, the pastoralists and the mining companies. I have listened as members of the committee have argued about the solution to this vexing question. I have honestly been dismayed to hear members in this place speak on this issue as if it is all black or white—that, because the government have the numbers in this place, God is on their side. I might sound naive and an idealist—it must be the teacher in me—but I implore the government to look very closely at what they are proposing to do through the implementation of this bill.

Let us look closely at what we on this side are putting forward in the second reading amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans). Let us look closely at the points raised by our amendment. It states:

(1) native title rights, including on pastoral leases, are fundamental legal property rights, acknow ledged and upheld as such by the High Court, and entitled to the same respect and protection as the property rights of non‐Indigenous Australians: any amendment of the Native Title Act in response to the Wik decision or for any other reason must fully reflect that reality;

(2) it is in the national interest that the Act balance and reconcile to the maximum possible extent the interests and reasonable expectations of both Indigenous Australians and other major stakeholders—farmers, miners and Australian taxpayers generally;

(3) it is both in the national interest, and in the interests of Indigenous Australians, farmers and miners, that there be the maximum possible predictability and certainty about the status of the Act and its practical operation;
(4) there is a need, in particular, to guarantee the constitutional validity of the legislation, by ensuring that legislation operates for the net benefit of Indigenous Australians;

(5) it is also in everyone's interest that the processes established by this legislation to deal with the registration and determination of claims, and the reconciliation of competing interests, be as effective and expeditious as possible;

(6) there are aspects of the Bill which may advance these objectives, in particular by encouraging and assisting the entering into of agreements, and by setting a stricter regime for the registration of claims;

I honestly could not understand why most people who have some interest in this issue would not support that. Paragraph (7) goes into greater detail about our perceived concerns of the deficiencies of the bill and it requires substantial amendment. I do not want to focus on that because members on this side have already done so. I want to reassert those first six points.

Let us forego the stupid idea that all wisdom lies in the party in government or, for that matter, in opposition. Let us work together through this amendment bill, as we debate it during the consideration in detail stage, and come up with a bill that does truly respect the rights of all parties and so end once and forever the divisive nature of this issue. I would ask all in this place to think closely and long on what I have said here tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Native Title Amendment Bill clearly demonstrates the differences between those opposite who are in government and Labor in government. Native title is one of the most important issues to face the Australian nation this century. It is an issue fundamentally linked to our sense of national identity. It is about whether we are a nation that has the political sophistication and tolerance to become a truly great multicultural society or whether we are a nation that will be permanently entwined in internal bickering and racial vilification.

SPEECH.PARA: Any legislation surrounding native title, therefore, has to be handled with long‐term vision. There has to be genuine statesmanship. There has to be a commitment to fairness and a healthy respect for the rights of all Australians. In particular, any legislation surrounding native title needs to be done by a government which acknowledges and honours the history and the common law rights that indigenous Australians possess.

This government is none of these things. Since coming to power last year, it has characterised itself as a mean‐spirited, self‐interested and incompetent government of the worst kind. Howard, his ministers and backbenchers mostly stood silent as the race debate enveloped the nation. They stood silent as young Vietnamese children got picked on in the playground in my electorate because they were different. They stood silent as black deaths in custody continued to rise. They stood silent as living conditions in some indigenous communities continued to be classed as Third World.

When they did respond, it was to give a boost to the cause of racial intolerance. Who can forget the so‐called `leadership' exhibited by John Howard when he addressed the Queensland division of the Liberal Party state council on 27 September 1996? He said then, in response to the first speech of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson):
In a sense the pall of censorship on certain issues has been lifted.

I think there has been that change and I think that's a very good thing . . . I welcome the fact that people can now talk about certain things without living in fear of being branded as a bigot or as a racist or any of the other . . . expressions that have been too carelessly flung around in this country . . .

That was the response of our esteemed Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to one of the most virulently racist, hate‐filled and factually incorrect speeches ever given in this parliament. The Prime Minister did not care that many Australians of ethnic and indigenous background were crying out for leadership on this issue. He did not care that many Australians were crying out for their Prime Minister to stand up to this avowed racist, the member for Oxley. He merely wanted to please the Queensland branch of the Liberal Party and the sectarian interests of many of their supporters and to appeal to the pollsters.

So what, predictably, did the government do when the Wik decision came down from the High Court? In a now common pattern of behaviour, it showed no leadership and it showed no respect for the rule of law in our country. Instead it played divisive politics aimed at getting a few of its wealthier grazier mates a better land deal. Nothing in the Wik decision actually changes the legal interests of those with pastoral leases. The value of the pastoral estate and the value of the security which the pastoral lease may provide remain unaltered. There are no compensation obligations on pastoralists flowing from the Wik decision and, indeed, the High Court ruled that, where native title rights and pastoral leases coexisted, native title rights were subordinate to the pastoral leases.

So why are we having this debate? The common law has not yet fully determined whether native title rights are permanently extinguished by the coexistence of a pastoral lease or whether they are merely temporarily suppressed. This has not, as yet, been decided by the High Court. Yet the government has decided to be above the law. They have decided to ignore the ruling of the highest court in our country. The government has decided to anticipate the outcomes of current court cases and conclude that pastoral leases do extinguish native title rights.

Pastoral leases have never given exclusive possession to the pastoralist. Under a pastoral lease you are not given the right to use the land exclusively; you are only given rights to use the land for specific pastoral purposes. The government plans to allow state governments to upgrade these pastoral leases to freehold or perpetual leases. So in one fell swoop they are planning to extinguish the legal property rights of indigenous Australians and enhance the property rights of wealthy Australians.

But it gets worse. The National Indigenous Working Group on Native Title points out in its position paper entitled `The indigenous position—coexistence, negotiation and certainty', that the government has acknowledged that the upgrading of pastoral leases to perpetual or exclusive leases would involve the acquisition of property and just terms compensation for native title holders. In other words, the Australian taxpayer will be paying for the upgrading of pastoral leases for wealthy landowners. That is not governing for all of us; that is governing for only a few of us: for those most wealthy at the expense of those who can least afford to miss out in our society today.

The problem is that the conservatives do not believe that indigenous Australians should have the same legally protected property rights as everyone else. They love to espouse the rhetoric of self‐help and economic independence for indigenous people. However, this does not mean that their rhetoric is backed up by action. The High Court has recognised that Aboriginal people have native title rights, fundamental legal property rights protected by law on an equal footing with the property rights of other Australians. This is as it should be. Property rights more than ever give indigenous people real economic independence.
In 1995 the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commissioner, Mick Dodson, spoke about the Liberal Party's attitude to the Hindmarsh Island affair. At that time he said:

I find it increasingly difficult not to be cynical about the fine rhetoric of cultural diversity. We can freely sing our songs and tell our stories—especially if those songs and stories can be marketed for a tidy profit. But the moment that the protection of those songs and stories may come into conflict with the economic interests of non‐indigenous society, we are told they have no place.

I am proud to associate myself with Mick Dodson in this House tonight, because the same is true about indigenous property rights. The goal of economic independence for indigenous Australians is acceptable only if economic independence does not entail indigenous Australians becoming economic equals with white Australians. They are allowed to be independent economically if it means being independentally poor. They are not allowed to live in economic equality with the rest of the Australian nation.

But there is a way to resolve these problems. On 9 October 1996 the New South Wales Labor government settled a native title claim at Crescent Head on the New South Wales north coast. The President of the National Native Title Tribunal, Justice Robert French, announced that the native title compact between the state government and the native title holders—the Dunghutti people—showed:
Mediation could work to produce agreements that address the aspirations of native title applicants and the broader concerns of local communities and governments.

Justice French also went on to explain that a number of processes contained in the Native Title Act were used in order to reach this historic agreement. The right to negotiate mechanism was used extensively. That is a key to this debate tonight. It is the same mechanism that this rotten government is trying to dramatically limit.

All who were involved in the Crescent Head negotiations reported the outcome to be a success. The local National Party MP, Bruce Jeffrey, issued a press release stating that he was pleased that the issue was `sorted out to the benefit of the entire Crescent Head Community'. Mr Kim Yeadon, the New South Wales Minister for Land and Water Conservation, said the settlement gave `security to non‐Aboriginal landholders whilst also compensating traditional native title holders'. The whole process, he said, was settled in a `balanced and reasonable way'.

That is the difference between those on this side of the House and the meanspirited mob on the other side. That is the difference between the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the former Prime Minister, Paul Keating. When the former Prime Minister, Paul Keating, saw injustice, he was a statesman, whereas when Howard sees injustice, he is a coward.
I conclude with a now famous quote from a speech made by Paul Keating to launch the International Year for the World's Indigenous People. He said:

The starting point might be to recognise that the problem starts with us non‐Aboriginal Australians. It begins, I think, with that act of recognition. Recognition that it was we who did the dispossessing. We took the traditional lands and smashed the traditional way of life. We brought the diseases, the alcohol. We committed the murders. TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw to the attention of the House a recent press release of the Minister for Health and Family Services, Dr Michael Wooldridge, headed `Review of hormone treatment for tall girls and short children reveals no evidence for concern'. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Department of Health and Family Services has reviewed three scientific articles describing research undertaken between 1959 and the mid‐1970's, in which hormones were administered to children in an effort to increase the height of short children and retard the growth of tall girls.
The review was requested by the Federal Minister for Health and Family Services, Dr Michael Wooldridge, and conducted by the Department in consultation with the relevant medical experts.
Dr Wooldridge said the department had examined the scientific and ethical aspects of the research.
`In relation to the short children treated with norethandrolone, the review found that serious long‐term side effects were unlikely,' Dr Wooldridge said.

`In relation to the hormone diethylstilboestrol used to retard the growth of tall girls, I am aware of the ethical issues and health concerns raised by women who had been involved in the research. I have been advised that there is no scientific evidence raising concerns about possible lasting side effects.'

In an article in the Melbourne Age , dated 10 October 1997, a spokeswoman for the tall girls who were used in this trial, Ms Janet Cregan‐Wood, said no such study had ever been carried out. She described Dr Wooldridge's response to the concerns of the women treated with DES as `totally inadequate'.

The Age revealed in June that more than one in 60 Victorian teenage girls were used for the trial between 1959 and the mid‐1970s by researchers from the Royal Children's Hospital and Melbourne University. The article stated:

Ms Cregan‐Wood said that more than half the women in a group formed to represent those used in the trial had suffered from ovarian cysts—one of the known side effects of DES—and other medical problems.
Other possible known side effects include infertility, cancer of the cervix and breast cancer.
It goes on to say:
Ms Cregan‐Wood said most of the girls who took part in the trial were not told it was an experiment or required to give informed consent.

According to the minister, the department looked at three scientific articles in consultation with relevant medical experts. Those articles were written by Dr Norman Wettenhall, a Melbourne physician. The first was entitled `Influence of norethandrolone on the stature of short children' in 1963, the second was entitled `Tall girls assessment and management' in 1965 and the third was entitled `Tall girls—A survey of 15 years of management and treatment' from volume 86 of the Journal of Adolescent Medicine .

As someone who shared the biomedical library at Monash University in 1976 with Dr Wooldridge, studying biochemistry, I would like to put this question to the minister: why would he ask the Department of Health and Family Services to review only three articles? Why was a more thorough review of the many other articles available not undertaken, especially those articles assessing the effects on tall girls and, subsequently, their daughters of the synthetic oestrogen that they were given—a drug called stilboestrol?

Why, for example, was the editorial in the British Medical Journal dated 20 April 1963 not reviewed? This article, entitled `Drugs for altering the growth of children', warned of the dangers of using norethandrolone, reporting cases of jaundice and two deaths. It also suggested that, under the influence of this drug, skeletal maturation occurred at such a rapid rate that the potential ultimate height was actually less than would have been the case had natural processes prevailed. I suspect that the department did not review this article and others like it because they did not provide the department's desired result, that being that there is nothing to worry about. It sounds like a bit of a whitewash to me.

Dr Wettenhall's paper `Influence of norethandrolone on the stature of short children' did, however, draw the same conclusion that norethandrolone reduced the mature height of the children for the same reasons. Yet no work was done to find out what happened to the Victorian children either physically or psychologically as a result of the steroid treatment, the known side effects of steroids being obesity, infertility and depression.

The minister said that the department had also examined the ethical aspects of the research and found efforts were made by researchers at the time to counsel the girls and their families on the likely effects of this treatment. A short female colleague of mine to whom I have spoken says that this is rubbish. They were not told that they were the subject of experiments, and they were certainly not told of the side effects. She and her family did not know that she had been given norethandrolone until 1992, some 30 years later. The psychological damage has been considerable, with many suffering severe depression and some becoming suicidal. These women were told that they were socially unacceptable. The treatment failed, and then they were dumped.

The Melbourne medical establishment, of which Dr Wooldridge is a part, has closed ranks. It is very difficult for victims to go and access their medical records. The director of research at the children's hospital, Graeme Barnes, wrote to the Age making the same claims as Dr Wooldridge that children were followed up and counselled. Repetition will not make this true; it simply is not. Dr Wooldridge's release also does not mention that norethandrolone is an anabolic steroid—a very nasty word. If it was okay to give steroids to children in the 1960s, why is there such a fuss about giving them to athletes now? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to bring to the House my electorate's concerns over the increases in private health insurance premiums. I am well aware the government inherited a depleted private health insurance system caused by the previous Labor government, where membership dropped from 61 per cent of Australians to a disgraceful 35 per cent. However, it is incumbent on this government to address past wrongs and provide the necessary incentives to raise the level of private health insurance membership. We have started to do this by introducing a tax rebate of $150 for single people, $250 for couples and $450 for families. Those people who do not pay tax can claim the rebate through their health fund. But since these incentives were introduced, health insurance premiums have risen twice, forcing people in my electorate to either cancel or seriously reconsider their membership.

SPEECH.PARA: My office has received a considerable number of letters and telephone complaints about these increased premiums. On top of this, Central Queensland's daily newspaper, the Morning Bulletin, conducted a survey on the issue which was published just recently. In this survey of a cross-section of the community, most people indicated that they will pull out or reconsider their health cover following these substantial increases and newly introduced excess and bed charges.

I have letters from elderly constituents who have been in health funds for 40 and 50 years and who are now being asked to pay approximately $45 per week for private health insurance with less cover than they have received in the past. This exorbitant fee is beyond the capacity of most pensioners. They are convinced that the health funds must consider them to be nothing more than a burden and therefore want them to be priced out of the system. This is wrong, it is sad and it needs to be addressed.

Additionally, these pensioners can now be faced with paying the gap—the gap between medical costs and the health fund rebate. This gap amount can be astronomical to a pensioner, someone on a low income or someone with no income at all, and it requires considerable investigation before one makes a commitment to enter a hospital.

The crisis has been caused because health fund payments in hospitals fall far short of matching increased costs. Health care is labour intensive, skill intensive, facility intensive and technologically rich. In fact, from entry to the operating table and on to recovery, it takes a team of up to 28 personnel to service a patient.

Health is big business. It is a big employer of highly trained professionals and less highly trained support staff. The industry makes up approximately 10 per cent of the gross national product of our communities. Yet governments are reluctant to put more money into the system. Governments are not prepared to pay to employ more staff to service this industry to meet the community's needs and to reduce the long queues in the public health system.

What we have is a public health system which is bleeding badly from its chronic financially anaemic coffers and a majority of private health funds lurching from crisis to crisis—and ready to fall over. As a government, we must be prepared to provide a big financial boost to hospitals on the proviso that they use the majority of this money to employ more staff. In that way, the long‐term member is not penalised in the short term—a get in and get out member. It also means that the elderly in our communities will not be paying higher fees as they age but will realise some reward for their long‐term commitment.

This is a prime opportunity to create employment all around the country, shorten public hospital queues and give people a long‐term incentive to join a private health fund. At the next election we cannot blame the former government for the mess they have left us, even though they are responsible. This coalition government is now responsible for the future of our health system—a system that needs a massive overhaul and injection of funds to turn this depressing problem around.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure most members of the House have seen the film Rainman , in which Dustin Hoffman gave an Oscar winning performance as a man with autism. Unfortunately, there are no such awards for the families of Australian people who experience autism. Recent information suggests that about one child in 1,000 in our population shows autistic tendencies, including problems with communication, behavioural difficulties and repetitive behaviour. The prognosis for most of these children is extremely poor.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a lifelong condition usually requiring lifelong commitment from family members in trying to make life as pleasant as possible for their relative. This care is made difficult by the inadequacy of knowledge about autism. Autism was only identified in 1943 and was first thought to be caused by obsessive, uncaring parents, a theory which has now been discredited. However, researchers are still not sure what causes the condition. Similarly, treatments vary from wearing specially coloured lenses, medication such as prozac and lithium, and play therapy, amongst a wide range of other choices. Many of these treatments are highly expensive, often controversial and have varying degrees of success.

Autism manifests itself in an equally wide range of ways. Many of the children diagnosed with autism are never able to communicate verbally. About one-third will develop problems with seizures, mostly during their teenage years. If you include children with Aspergers Disorder—and the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) might confirm my pronunciation—about five out of 10 will have an intellectual disability.

The only certainty in this area is the importance of having a loving, caring family around the autistic person. Parents and other relatives are desperately searching for the answers to their many questions and are doing their utmost to provide the highest quality of life for their loved ones. Their search is being made more difficult in Australia by the fact that all the services for autistic people take place on an uncoordinated state basis rather than a federal basis. This means that information sharing, available resources and general information to families caring for an autistic person are fragmented and laborious to track down.

This is why the recent National Conference of the National Association for Autism, made up of state based autism groups, has endorsed the need to establish a permanent recognised peak body for the autistic and their families. The association has applied to the Department of Health and Family Services for seed funding to enable them to set up the necessary structures to put this in place. I wish them success in being granted this funding and in achieving a higher profile for autism in government departments.

There are several examples of the lack of recognition for this disorder that deeply concern the association. For example, the new questionnaire being used to determine the level of family need for child disability allowances does not make allowance for the highly individualistic nature of the autistic child. There is a need for autism to be recognised as a discrete disability condition and a recognition that some high functioning individuals still have high support needs.

In addition to these requirements, government departments need to realise that autism is often misdiagnosed and people can be incorrectly labelled as suffering from obsessive-compulsive disorder or schizophrenia. Generally, autism disorders have been grouped with intellectual disability or psychological problems and not treated as an individual group. This attitude takes us back to the time before 1943, when the autistic were diagnosed as mentally ill or retarded and their true condition was not discovered.

The government needs to recognise this important group of Australians and their families. These people should not be labelled as intellectually disabled or mentally ill. Certainly, more support must be given to their carers. I emphasise that point.

BREAK.PARA: The current policies of state and federal governments favour a broadbanding approach to disability resource funding as opposed to the specialist approach that is essential to people with autism and their families. In particular, there needs to be more funding for adults affected by autism to increase their integration into the community. These Australians deserve an informed, appropriate response to their needs. I add my support to the National Association for Autism in its attempt to get a better deal for these Australians. I urge the government in the strongest terms to provide immediate assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —For some time I have been concerned about the morale of the defence forces, so much so that I joined the Liberal Party to work towards a position where I could have some influence upon decisions in the ADF that have led to such dispirited troops. The case of LAC Woods is a good example of the poor leadership and inconsistent decision making that is so bad for morale. CAS has recommended his discharge for dishonesty in relation to a $200 travel claim for which he has been tried and punished under the Defence Force Discipline Act.

SPEECH.PARA: LAC Woods had an outstanding record for five years in support units before coming to No. 33 Squadron operations. There are dozens of character references from other RAAF personnel to this effect, and these people will be watching with interest the outcome of the Woods case. He joined the RAAF motivated to succeed and, once he got through basic training, has been working hard to improve himself and obtain career goals. No doubt he has adopted many of the RAAF cultures in the various work environments of the ADF.

These cultures develop from what I term `morality creep'. This is where, over a period of time, a unit allows little diversions from the strict rules or allows interpretations of those rules which then become culture. Gradually everyone knows the limits in the interpretation of the rules and an accepted standard of behaviour develops. The only ones who are disciplined for low standards of behaviour are those who fall out of favour with the chain of command. This was LAC Woods's only crime.

I have seen this happen with paying compliments, claiming allowances, obeying orders, performing guard duty and enforcing standards of dress and behaviour in the messes. These cultures do exist and will continue while high profile officers are not discharged for defrauding the Commonwealth of substantially more than the $200 LAC Woods has claimed and repaid. Such inconsistencies have created the attitude in the ADF that `everyone is doing it with no disadvantage, so I am a mug if I do not'. This morality creep quickly overtakes the new recruit and saps ethics, enthusiasm and initiative. Promotion depends on a good personal relationship with your superior and how many favours you perform. Morality creep continues.

After seven years of disruptive policy changes and willy‐nilly personnel reductions, it is hard to convince remaining personnel that there are not double standards in the ADF. Ad hoc decisions to discharge LAC Woods but not Squadron Leader Whiting or Wing Commander Foley for the same thing are no way to develop the personnel required for a modern defence force.

The consequences of low morale were evident in No. 33 Squadron at the time of the 707 accident, which killed five squadron members. Do not underestimate morale as a real resource in any battle. Everyone who wrote a reference for Woods, everyone who has worked with him and everyone who has an opinion on the different treatment between officers and troops will discuss the Woods case—to the detriment of No. 33 Squadron leadership and RAAF leadership overall.

I believe that, due to the promotion methods in the RAAF, personnel with very little leadership skills have been placed in key positions from which they can destroy the morale of a unit and add substantially to the cost of running a defence force, the cost of training personnel to replace those who leave, the cost of mistakes due to inexperience—such as the 707 accident—the cost of cultures of allowance abuse and pilfering, and the cost of legal proceedings to resolve personnel issues which should have been resolved at the grassroots level—for example, the Butterworth board of inquiry into personal relations between a CO and his troops is estimated to have cost $6 million. Now we have a similar inquiry into a navy culture of customs fraud. I am interested to see which ranks will be sacrificed to public opinion in that inquiry.

LAC Woods has informed me that his chain of command at No. 33 Squadron contained personnel with whom he had come into conflict at times when they were all in separate units. It takes a great deal of leadership to avoid the obvious conclusion that those superiors thought little of LAC Woods and, as soon as an opportunity to get even with LAC Woods became available, they made his life as difficult as possible.

This is easy in the military where the official rules demand one standard of behaviour but the accepted norm is another. In the ordinary course of events, no-one is given a formal warning for variation from the rules within the accepted unofficial standard. When the people in your chain of command wish to make it difficult for you, it is easy to rely on the official standards to award sanctions and ultimately demand your resignation. LAC Woods is a victim of these double standards, with no recourse to a union or separate organisation not guided by the views of his superiors.

LAC Woods's previous five years of service and numerous references speak for themselves. How can someone with such a record, who was selected above many others for one of the most sought‐after flight steward positions, lose touch so badly with the required standards within a four‐month period? There are many people at Richmond who have an interest in this case because, if it can happen to LAC Woods, it can happen to them if they fall out of favour with the chain of command. Try rebuilding morale in that atmosphere.

I think we should be going back to basics in recruit training and change these work cultures with positive, consistent leadership. There should be an independent union for ADF personnel with more teeth than AFUR to ensure this type of bastardisation cannot happen.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Has a decision been made by the Specialist Medical Review Council relating to cases of micro trauma leading to a right for compensation for war‐related arthritis; if so, (a) what progress has the Repatriation Medical Authority made in regard to the need for resulting Statements of Principles and (b) will the principles be retrospective for claims lodged (i) prior to or (ii) after the 1994 changes from reasonable hypothesis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes.
(a) The Specialist Medical Review Council (SMRC) published a decision concerning osteoarthrosis on 24 March 1997. Notification appeared in the Government Gazette on 2 April 1997.

The decision of the SMRC was to recommend to the Repatriation Medical Authority (RMA) that they reconsider the issue "having regard to the reasons for decision of the Council, the information that was available to the Repatriation Medical Authority when it made that Statement of Principles, together with any further information that may arise from any later studies relating to osteoarthrosis." The Council did not propose any alternative Statements of Principles.

Meanwhile, the RMA had notified on 26 February 1997 that it was undertaking a formal investigation of micro trauma and osteoarthrosis. After the publication of the SMRC's recommendations, the RMA took these recommendations into account in its own investigation of micro trauma and osteoarthritis. The Authority will issue new Statements of Principles if it finds appropriate medical and scientific evidence for a change.

(b) (i) Any new Statements of Principles will not be retrospective for claims lodged prior to the 1994 changes that have been finally decided. If there are any claims lodged prior to 1994 that have not been finalised, they will be decided either by:
. any new Statement of Principles, if it would lead to the acceptance of that claim; or
. if there is no change to the Statement of Principles, the law and evidence as it stood prior to the 1994 changes,
whichever has the best result for the claimant.

(b) (ii) For claims made after the 1994 changes, any new Statement of Principles will apply to decisions made after notification by the RMA in the Government Gazette of that new Instrument. Any claims made after the 1994 changes, that had been finally decided under the previous Statement of Principles, will require a new claim to be submitted to the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 25 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to allegations that the freighter Zim Sydney has on board three containers of illegal hazardous waste loaded at Sydney on 12 September 1997.
(2) If so, what steps will the Government take to stop further illegal exports.
(3) Will the Minister take steps to compel the return of the waste from Hong Kong if it is found that the material was exported illegally.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Under the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989 there are strict penalties for offences under the Act, including fines of up $A1 million and imprisonment for executive officers of companies for up to 5 years.

I note that the maximum penalties under the Act were significantly strengthened by amendments to the Act passed under the Howard Government. The Howard Government's amendments also expanded the scope of the Act to ensure our obligations under the Basel Convention are met. The previous Labor Government failed to adequately address these issues.

The Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories has taken steps to appoint expert inspectors under the Act to conduct searches on an ad hoc basis and has undertaken an educational program to ensure that Australian exporters and importers are aware of the requirements relating to international movements of hazardous wastes. A Memorandum of Understanding on compliance issues will be signed with the Australian Customs Service in the near future.

(3) The Hong Kong Government has asked that the waste be returned to Australia as their investigations found the waste to be hazardous. We are taking all necessary action to ensure that the waste is returned to Australia as a matter of priority, as required under the Basel Convention.
